And when Britain needed to rebuild, they chose more austerity.”The picture has been particularly bleak for investment, which fell at an annual average rate of -0.2 per cent&nbspbetween the second quarter of 2017 and the same period this year. By contrast, the rest of the OECD nations averaged 3.4 annual growth during that time.Once public and housing investment is stripped out, UK business investment was even weaker over the period, falling at an annual rate of -1.3 per cent.“We need leaders who will take on the UK’s rigged economy,”&nbspMs O’Grady added. “And we need a plan for world-class public services, modern industry and decent jobs.”Workers have paid the price for lacklustre growth, the TUC said. That claim was supported by separate analysis from the Resolution Foundation, published on Thursday. It forecasts&nbspthat British workers will only see average wages surpass their 2007 peak in November or December this year – finally bringing an end to the longest period of stagnant wages in 200 years.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailWhile Brexit is seen as the key battleground of the upcoming general election, the economy will also be significant.&nbspAverage hourly pay among workers under 40 years old – who have polled heavily in favour of the Labour Party since the last election – are still being paid less than the same age group were before the financial crisis.Average pay across the southeast, Northern Ireland and the East Midlands regions is still well short of its pre-crisis health, the Resolution Foundation said.John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor, said:&nbsp“The Conservatives’ mismanagement of both the economy and Brexit is having a disastrous impact on our economy, undermining wages, jobs and living standards.”Nye Cominetti, an economic analyst at the Resolution Foundation, said: “Britain’s post-crisis pay downturn has been deeper and longer-lasting than anyone could have predicted, and caused a major squeeze on household incomes across the country.“After 12 long years, Britain is finally on the brink of returning to ‘peak pay’. This is a big living standards milestone and a relief for households after an unprecedented pay downturn.“But politicians tempted to use the return of ‘peak pay’ to claim that Britain ‘has never had it so good’ should remember that pay for millions of workers is still below pre-crisis levels, and that our pay downturn has left average pay £138 a week off track.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: walking exercise global economy jogging fitness world health organisation
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Fewer sick days and longer working lives would give economic growth a shot in the armThe world economy could be boosted by as much as $100bn&nbsp(£78bn) a year if employers successfully encouraged their staff to meet World Health Organisation guidelines on exercise, according to an analysis of the economic impact of activity.Adding an extra 15 minutes of daily walking, or jogging a steady one kilometre each day, would improve productivity and extend life expectancy - leading to more economic growth, the study by the health insurance group Vitality and the think tank Rand&nbspEurope found.The economic boost would come from lower mortality rates - in other words keeping more people alive, working and contributing to the economy for longer, the study’s authors said, and from employees taking fewer days off sick.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHans Pung, Rand&nbspEurope’s president, said the study highlighted “a significant relationship between inactivity and productivity loss” and should give policymakers and employers “new perspectives on how to enhance the productivity of their populations”.The WHO recommends that all adults should take at least 150 minutes of moderate exercise, or 75 minutes of vigorous exercise, a week. In a study last year it found that around 40 per cent of adults in the United States, 36 per cent in Britain and 14 per cent in China did too little exercise to stay healthy.Created with Sketch. Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.410 Bow and Three Mills, London410 Bow and Three Mills, LondonThe RandVitality study was based in part on data from about 120,000 people across seven countries. It then modelled and projected the potential economic benefits of increased physical activity globally and for 23 inidual countries.It found that if all adults aged between 18 and 64 walked 15 more minutes a day, it could increase world economic output by some $100bn year on year.It also found that physically inactive 40-year-olds could increase their life expectancy, on average, by 3.2 years, by introducing 20 minutes of jogging a day.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Trading floors seek to change reputation for gruelling hours and macho working culture&nbspCity traders have called for a shorter working day in a bid to attract more women and working parents into a profession with a reputation for long hours and a male-dominated culture.Two lobbying groups wrote to stock exchanges across Europe calling for the current 8am-4:30pm day to be cut to 9am-4pm.A 90-minute reduction in hours would create “more efficient markets” as well as increase&nbspersity and wellbeing, the Investment Association&nbspand Association for Financial Markets in Europe&nbspsaid.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTraders are often expected to begin work long before the markets open and a culture of long hours under stressful conditions has been found to negatively affect mental health and deter those with families or other caring commitments.The London Stock Exchange said it would consider the proposals.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 51Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.British Prime Minister Boris Johnson makes a statement to announce the general election at Downing Street in London, BritainLiberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson speaking at the launch of their general election campaign at the Institute of Civil Engineers in LondonPelicans in St James's Park in central LondonDancers perform a mass Ghoomar dance during Diwali celebrations in Trafalgar Square, LondonCampaigners listen as SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon addresses a rally calling for Scottish independence in GlasgowPolice and recovery workers remove a damaged bus from the scene of a crash in Sevenoaks Road, south-east London. title: conservative labour spending plans end austerity uk
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Economists and business groups welcome end of austerity as parties lay out major shift in policy after years of cutsBusiness groups and economists welcomed the end of austerity as both major&nbspparties laid out plans to dramatically ramp up spending, signalling a major shift in policy on Thursday.But chancellor Sajid Javid was also accused of picking fruit from the magic money tree” which his party has repeatedly invoked to mock Labour’s spending plans.Nick Macpherson, the former permanent secretary to the Treasury, labelled both Conservative and Labour’s proposals as “incontinent”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMr Javid ripped up the government’s own restrictive spending rules, pledging to borrow to invest in infrastructure. The British Chamber of Commerce said it had been calling for such a change for “many years”.The BCC called on ministers to raise their sights even higher to end the UK’s “dismal” rate of investment in long-term infrastructure.Created with Sketch.Top 10 marginal seats to watch at the general election Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Currently held by the SNP investment is set to return to levels not seen since the 1970s, but there are differences in approach between the two.Labour’s plans for £400bn of new infrastructure were labelled “especially ambitious” by the non-partisan Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS).That would take the UK from being near the bottom&nbspinternationally&nbspfor government investment, to the top.“The key challenge for a government seeking to deliver investment on this scale – particularly in a short timeframe – will be finding worthwhile and viable projects in which to invest,” said Ben Zaranko, research economist at the IFS.“Shortages in the number of suitably skilled construction workers, a dearth of ‘shovel-ready’ projects, and practical issues relating to delivery will be challenges the next government will need to think carefully about how to overcome.”Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe Resolution Foundation hailed the shift from a debate narrowly focused on reducing the nation’s debt to one that takes in a more expansive view of spending and long-term investment.Javid tears up his fiscal rules to borrow for investment“With the low cost of borrowing, austerity Britain is going to turn into hard-hat Britain whoever wins the next election,” said&nbspJames Smith, research director at the Resolution Foundation.“This shifts the focus to ensuring that investment delivers real returns not just higher debt.”Henri Murison, director of the Northern Powerhouse Partnership said Mr Javid’s plan for an extra £20bn of infrastructure annually was a welcome intervention and would make a large expansion of railways in the North of England viable.“These are the right priorities, and all parties in their manifestos will need to show the fiscal credibility of their plans in order for anyone here in the North, business or iniduals, to take them seriously, Mr Murison said.Others were less enamoured with the new policy direction.An editorial in former chancellor George Osborne’s Evening Standard said: “In a previous age, the Tories would make hay with the Labour magic money tree. But this Conservative leadership is also picking the fruit from its branches.“Boris Johnson’s attitude to the public finances is simple: I’m in charge, and if I don’t spend it someone else will.“No 10 wants to make billions of pounds worth of commitments on spending and tax cuts during this campaign.”Free market think tank the Institute for Economic Affairs accused both parties of abandoning fiscal restraint”.It said: “In order to make the most of the opportunities that lie ahead, politicians should be focusing on allowing taxpayers to keep more of their wages, enabling more consumer choice and reducing inefficiencies in order to save money and improve services, instead of bribing tax payers with their own money in a bid to win votes.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: soul trailer pixar new movie watch jamie foxx tina fey release date
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Film coming in 2020Pixar&nbsphas unveiled an emotional first trailer for&nbspSoul,&nbspa new animated film coming to the studio next year.The clip, which lasts one minute and 30 seconds, focuses on Joe Gardner, the protagonist voiced by Jamie Foxx.Gardner, a middle school music teacher in New York City, books an exciting jazz music gig before falling into a manhole on the street.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe fall causes his soul to get separated from his body as Gardner is transported to another dimension.&nbspGardner, as it turns out, has landed in the You Seminar, a training facility for young souls&nbspwho must become sufficiently developed before being placed in newborn babies.Created with Sketch. Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.125 25. I Am MotherRickety-looking science fiction thriller I Am Mother delivers where it counts with a twisting, turning plot and several genuine surprises. In the far future, a maternal robot (voiced by Rose Byrne) raises a young woman (Clara Rugaard) as her daughter. But when an outsider (Hilary Swank) makes her way to their bunker their perfect life is shattered forever.In Private Life, a bohemian middle-aged couple struggle to have a child. Kathryn Hahn and Paul Giamatti are hilarious and poignant. And the pathos is piled on as twenty-something college drop-out Sadie (Kayli Carter) parachutes into their life. High-jinks follow, though director Tamara Jenkins ensures the existential sadness that has become part of the protagonists daily life never quite fades. Steven Soderbergh has become something of a Netflix regular, with his Meryl Streep-starring The Laundromat recently premiering on the service. His earlier movie High Flying Bird is about a basketball agent (André Holland) in a game of skulduggery between players (mostly black and uneducated) and team owners (white and wealthy). It’s a great sports film and also a commentary on the racial and social schisms that ide America. 425 22. I Don't Feel at Home in this World AnymoreA quirky though ultimately quite dark indie movie about two misfits, Ruth (Melanie Lynskey) and Tony (Elijah Wood), on the trail off a burglar who made off with a silver spoon belonging to Ruth’s grandmother. Whimsical on the surface, I Don’t Feel at Home in this World Anymore is in fact a meditation on what happens when you’ve had enough of life’s fundamental unfairness and lash out. Team-up heist movie Triple Frontier stars Ben Affleck, Oscar Isaac, Charlie Hunnum and Pedro Pascal as old marine corps buddies headed to South America for one final pay-day. It’s hugely flawed – but Affleck is convincing as a guy losing his way amidst orce and middle age. And JC Chandor (Collateral) directs the action scenes with pizzaz. It comes close to being a great action flick for grown-ups before ultimately fizzling out. 625 20. A Futile and Stupid GestureStraight-to-video production values don’t do it any favours, but A Futile and Stupid Gesture – a biopic about the founder of American satirical magazine National Lampoon, Douglas Kenney (Will Forte) – has its heart in the right place. It’s a by turns poignant and hilarious accent of Forte’s rise, his descent into drugs and infidelity – and his strained relationship with Lampoon co-founder Henry Beard (an unrecognisable Domhnall Gleeson). Critics trounced this stylised horror starring Jake Gyllenhaal are a vainglorious art critic. Certainly, as commentary on the vacuousness of the art world it’s a whole lot of stating the obvious. Yet enjoyed as a Argento-esque OTT romp, Velvet Buzzsaw is a delight, as director Dan Gilroy subjects his victims to a series of ever more absurdist and grisly ends. El Camino would be higher on the list were it not for the fact it really isn’t a film. Best thought of as a two-hour Breaking Bad episode, it takes up the story of Jesse Pinkman after he’s fled the dying Walter White and driven into the blue yonder. The milieu is the familiar New Mexico underworld of Breaking Bad and its gentler prequel, Better Call Saul. BB fans will nonetheless relish a return, however brief, to the Vince Gilligan expanded universe. Plus all – yes ALL – your faves from the Ballad of Walter White are back for cameos. With his Doctor Sleep adaptation forthcoming, Mike Flanagan has established himself as the latter-day top dog off Stephen King retellings. He gave us a taste of what he was capable of via his gruelling adaptation of 1992 King novel Gerald's Game, which is about a woman (Carla Gugino) who ends up bound to a bed when her husband dies during a sex game. Don’t try this at a home – or anyone else for that matter – kids. Former Daily Show correspondent Jessica Williams is a revelation in The Incredible Jessica James, which follows a romantically adrift young playwright who tries to come to terms with a break up by projecting blinding over-confidence. She strikes up an unlikely chemistry with Chris O’Dowd’s awkward everyman – with results that achieve a rarefied mix of funny and sweet. Sandra Bullock in a blindfold whispering to two terrified children might not sound like the stuff of blockbuster gold. Sci-fi horror Bird Box is certainly flawed. It also had the ill fortune to come out six months after the thematically adjacent A Quiet Place. Nonetheless, there’s an undeniable pulpy thrill to this tale of aliens that drive you mad on sight (hence the blind-folds). Keep an eye out, too, for a fantastic cameo from Tom Hollander. Ali Wong and Randall Park play former childhood sweethearts from San Fransisco whose lives take very different paths after they consummate their friendship. She becomes a celebrity chef engaged to a dead-eyed property developer he’s a home town schlub still living with his dad. Screwball antics ensue as their paths cross again. So far, so cliche. But there are enough surprises – and one hilarious cameo – to prevent Always Be My Maybe feeling hopelessly formulaic. Netflix has become an unexpected champion of the humble romcom and To All The Boys I’ve Loved Before was the movie that established its reputation in the genre. Lana Condor plays a shy high-school student who writes pretend letters to her crushes. But when the missives are stolen and made public, she feels obliged to enter a fake relationship in order to preserve her dignity. All your favourite romcom tropes are ticked off – but with a knowingness that falls satisfyingly short of cynical.1425 12. The Fundamentals of CaringPaul Rudd takes a break from Ant-Man to play the carer of teenager Trevor (Craig Roberts), who has muscular dystrophy, in The Fundamentals of Caring. A heart-warming road movie ensues as they somehow end up crossing America in the company of flinty hitchhiker Dot (Selena Gomez). Rudd’s likability is dialled all the way up in a feel-good weepie sure to shred the heartstrings1525 11. Mowgli: Legend of the Jungle King of motion capture Andy Serkis ropes in some famous pals – Christian Bale, Cate Blanchett. Benedict Cumberbatch etc – for a fang-baring tilt at Rudyard Kipling. Shunted back because of Disney’s own “live action” Jungle Book remake, Mowgli: Legend of the Jungle is far grittier – a children’s movie with enough tooth and claw not to feel like a fairytale. Eddie Murphy puts in one of his best performances in years in Dolemite Is My Name, a biopic about Blaxploitation comedian Rudy Ray Moore, whose potty-mouthed albums and movies in the mid Seventies were credited with helping invent hip hop. Moore’s “Dolemite” character was based on old black homeless man he encountered in San Fransisco and caused both a sensation and a scandal at the time. Murphy brings this complex figure to life with an alternately hilarious and affecting turn. Lovecraftian weirdness by the bucketful from director Alex Garland. Natalie Portman heads a team of researchers venturing into a quarantined swampland where the laws of nature have been rebuilt from the cellular level up. Annihilation is mind-bending body horror, with echoes of Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey.1825 8. Beasts of No NationCary Joji Fukunaga will shortly make his Bond debut with No Time To Die. But he was better known for directing original season of True Detective when his adaptation of Uzodinma Iweala’s Ghanian civil war novel Beasts of No Nation was acquired by Netflix. It’s a nightmarish tale of child soldiers dehumanised by conflict, with Idris Elba chilling as the adult commander of the boy combatants. Netflix has been churning out serviceable horror movies for several years now. Apostle, a Wicker Man updating by Raid director Gareth Evans, features the standard feral yokels, to which he brings his own innovation via oceans of gore. Dan Stevens is a naive outsider who, in 1905, travels to a remote Welsh island hoping to locate his vanished sister. He discovers a cult headed by Michael Sheen’s crazed preacherman, a whole lot of trouble and something terrible hiding in the dark.With Bong Joon-ho’s Parasite winning the Palme d'Or, what better moment to revisit his brilliantly weird and charming morality fable from 2017. Co-written with John Ronson, Okja is a by turns heart-warming and chilling story of a young girl (Ahn Seo-hyun) and her friendship with the titular bio-engineered super-pig. It sounds, and frequently is, bonkers but Joon-ho plays with our heartstrings as if manipulating a Straarius, while Cate Blanchett is outstanding as an evil tech messiah masquerading as an environmentalist. 2125 5. The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected)Adam Sandler, Ben Stiller, Dustin Hoffman, and Emma Thompson head the cast in Noah Baumbach’s comedy drama The Meyerowitz Stories about worldly Manhattanites struggling with their lives of sophisticated privilege. Baumbach is on solid ground marshalling the inter-familial tension. But he also reminds us why he’s a master at locating universal truths within the self-involved lives of neurotic Americans. Mudbound is an unflinching survey of race and politics in the Southern United States immediately before and after the Second World War. Carey Mulligan and Mary J Blige head the cast, while Dee Rees guides the story with tremendous tautness. Mudbound was expected to receive a clean sweep of Oscar nominations in 2017. In the end it received just four, in relatively minor categories. The first rumblings of Hollywood’s hostility towards streaming and its impact on cinema? 2325 3. The Other Side of the WindFor a reminder how unhinged film-making became in the Seventies, buckle up and lose yourself in this posthumous restoration of never-completed Orson Welles movie, The Other Side of the Wind. What would have been Welles’s swansong is a maniacal, meta meditation on art and fame, with John Huston playing a buccaneering director – in essence, a heightened composite of himself and Welles. There are also parts for Peter Bogdanovich and Dennis Hopper. Welles’s editor, Bob Murawski, together with Bogdanovich and Welles’s daughter Beatrice, assembled the cut from 100 hours of footage. It only occasionally makes sense – but, as an experience, it's unforgettable. 2425 2. The Ballad of Buster ScruggsWhen Netflix asked the Coen brothers to make a binge-friendly TV series, Hollywood’s quirkiest siblings obviously went their own way. This anthology movie, titled The Ballad of Buster Scruggs, features six stories set amid the Coens’ deeply quirky and revisionist take on the Old West. The spirit of their classic O Brother, Where Art Thou? is tapped enthusiastically, with Liam Neeson, Zoe Kazan, Tim Blake Nelson, James Franco and Tom Waits heading the starry cast. The privileged Mexico City childhood of director Alfonso Cuarón inspired his affecting, quasi-autobiographical treatise on class, privilege and love. Yalitza Aparicio is the semi-invisible maid to a wealthy family, her life a story of small moments unfolding against the backdrop of political upheaval. Netflix was denied its Best Picture Oscar for Roma, but Cuarón was an uncontroversial pick for Best Director at the 2018 awards.  125 25. Yet enjoyed as a Argento-esque OTT romp, Velvet Buzzsaw is a delight, as director Dan Gilroy subjects his victims to a series of ever more absurdist and grisly ends. El Camino would be higher on the list were it not for the fact it really isn’t a film. Best thought of as a two-hour Breaking Bad episode, it takes up the story of Jesse Pinkman after he’s fled the dying Walter White and driven into the blue yonder. The milieu is the familiar New Mexico underworld of Breaking Bad and its gentler prequel, Better Call Saul. BB fans will nonetheless relish a return, however brief, to the Vince Gilligan expanded universe. Plus all – yes ALL – your faves from the Ballad of Walter White are back for cameos. With his Doctor Sleep adaptation forthcoming, Mike Flanagan has established himself as the latter-day top dog off Stephen King retellings. He gave us a taste of what he was capable of via his gruelling adaptation of 1992 King novel Gerald's Game, which is about a woman (Carla Gugino) who ends up bound to a bed when her husband dies during a sex game. Don’t try this at a home – or anyone else for that matter – kids. Former Daily Show correspondent Jessica Williams is a revelation in The Incredible Jessica James, which follows a romantically adrift young playwright who tries to come to terms with a break up by projecting blinding over-confidence. She strikes up an unlikely chemistry with Chris O’Dowd’s awkward everyman – with results that achieve a rarefied mix of funny and sweet. Sandra Bullock in a blindfold whispering to two terrified children might not sound like the stuff of blockbuster gold. Sci-fi horror Bird Box is certainly flawed. It also had the ill fortune to come out six months after the thematically adjacent A Quiet Place. Nonetheless, there’s an undeniable pulpy thrill to this tale of aliens that drive you mad on sight (hence the blind-folds). Keep an eye out, too, for a fantastic cameo from Tom Hollander. Ali Wong and Randall Park play former childhood sweethearts from San Fransisco whose lives take very different paths after they consummate their friendship. She becomes a celebrity chef engaged to a dead-eyed property developer he’s a home town schlub still living with his dad. Screwball antics ensue as their paths cross again. So far, so cliche. But there are enough surprises – and one hilarious cameo – to prevent Always Be My Maybe feeling hopelessly formulaic. Netflix has become an unexpected champion of the humble romcom and To All The Boys I’ve Loved Before was the movie that established its reputation in the genre. Lana Condor plays a shy high-school student who writes pretend letters to her crushes. But when the missives are stolen and made public, she feels obliged to enter a fake relationship in order to preserve her dignity. All your favourite romcom tropes are ticked off – but with a knowingness that falls satisfyingly short of cynical.1425 12. The Fundamentals of CaringPaul Rudd takes a break from Ant-Man to play the carer of teenager Trevor (Craig Roberts), who has muscular dystrophy, in The Fundamentals of Caring. A heart-warming road movie ensues as they somehow end up crossing America in the company of flinty hitchhiker Dot (Selena Gomez). Rudd’s likability is dialled all the way up in a feel-good weepie sure to shred the heartstrings1525 11. Mowgli: Legend of the Jungle King of motion capture Andy Serkis ropes in some famous pals – Christian Bale, Cate Blanchett. Benedict Cumberbatch etc – for a fang-baring tilt at Rudyard Kipling. Shunted back because of Disney’s own “live action” Jungle Book remake, Mowgli: Legend of the Jungle is far grittier – a children’s movie with enough tooth and claw not to feel like a fairytale. Eddie Murphy puts in one of his best performances in years in Dolemite Is My Name, a biopic about Blaxploitation comedian Rudy Ray Moore, whose potty-mouthed albums and movies in the mid Seventies were credited with helping invent hip hop. Moore’s “Dolemite” character was based on old black homeless man he encountered in San Fransisco and caused both a sensation and a scandal at the time. Murphy brings this complex figure to life with an alternately hilarious and affecting turn. Lovecraftian weirdness by the bucketful from director Alex Garland. Natalie Portman heads a team of researchers venturing into a quarantined swampland where the laws of nature have been rebuilt from the cellular level up. Annihilation is mind-bending body horror, with echoes of Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey.1825 8. Beasts of No NationCary Joji Fukunaga will shortly make his Bond debut with No Time To Die. But he was better known for directing original season of True Detective when his adaptation of Uzodinma Iweala’s Ghanian civil war novel Beasts of No Nation was acquired by Netflix. It’s a nightmarish tale of child soldiers dehumanised by conflict, with Idris Elba chilling as the adult commander of the boy combatants. Netflix has been churning out serviceable horror movies for several years now. Apostle, a Wicker Man updating by Raid director Gareth Evans, features the standard feral yokels, to which he brings his own innovation via oceans of gore. Dan Stevens is a naive outsider who, in 1905, travels to a remote Welsh island hoping to locate his vanished sister. He discovers a cult headed by Michael Sheen’s crazed preacherman, a whole lot of trouble and something terrible hiding in the dark.With Bong Joon-ho’s Parasite winning the Palme d'Or, what better moment to revisit his brilliantly weird and charming morality fable from 2017. Co-written with John Ronson, Okja is a by turns heart-warming and chilling story of a young girl (Ahn Seo-hyun) and her friendship with the titular bio-engineered super-pig. It sounds, and frequently is, bonkers but Joon-ho plays with our heartstrings as if manipulating a Straarius, while Cate Blanchett is outstanding as an evil tech messiah masquerading as an environmentalist. 2125 5. The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected)Adam Sandler, Ben Stiller, Dustin Hoffman, and Emma Thompson head the cast in Noah Baumbach’s comedy drama The Meyerowitz Stories about worldly Manhattanites struggling with their lives of sophisticated privilege. Baumbach is on solid ground marshalling the inter-familial tension. But he also reminds us why he’s a master at locating universal truths within the self-involved lives of neurotic Americans. Mudbound is an unflinching survey of race and politics in the Southern United States immediately before and after the Second World War. Carey Mulligan and Mary J Blige head the cast, while Dee Rees guides the story with tremendous tautness. Mudbound was expected to receive a clean sweep of Oscar nominations in 2017. In the end it received just four, in relatively minor categories. The first rumblings of Hollywood’s hostility towards streaming and its impact on cinema? 2325 3. The Other Side of the WindFor a reminder how unhinged film-making became in the Seventies, buckle up and lose yourself in this posthumous restoration of never-completed Orson Welles movie, The Other Side of the Wind. What would have been Welles’s swansong is a maniacal, meta meditation on art and fame, with John Huston playing a buccaneering director – in essence, a heightened composite of himself and Welles. There are also parts for Peter Bogdanovich and Dennis Hopper. Welles’s editor, Bob Murawski, together with Bogdanovich and Welles’s daughter Beatrice, assembled the cut from 100 hours of footage. It only occasionally makes sense – but, as an experience, it's unforgettable. 2425 2. The Ballad of Buster ScruggsWhen Netflix asked the Coen brothers to make a binge-friendly TV series, Hollywood’s quirkiest siblings obviously went their own way. This anthology movie, titled The Ballad of Buster Scruggs, features six stories set amid the Coens’ deeply quirky and revisionist take on the Old West. The spirit of their classic O Brother, Where Art Thou? is tapped enthusiastically, with Liam Neeson, Zoe Kazan, Tim Blake Nelson, James Franco and Tom Waits heading the starry cast. The privileged Mexico City childhood of director Alfonso Cuarón inspired his affecting, quasi-autobiographical treatise on class, privilege and love. Yalitza Aparicio is the semi-invisible maid to a wealthy family, her life a story of small moments unfolding against the backdrop of political upheaval. Netflix was denied its Best Picture Oscar for Roma, but Cuarón was an uncontroversial pick for Best Director at the 2018 awards.  In the trailer, Gardner encounters 22, an especially non-existential soul voiced by Tina Fey. When&nbspasked what she wants to be remembered for, 22 replies Probably for... doing this funny cowboy dance, before launching into a demonstration of the goofy number.The new teaser is full of inspirational&nbsptidbits prompting viewers to reflect on their higher purpose in life, such as: We only have a short time on this planet. You want to become the person that you were born to be? Don't waste your time on all the junk of life. Spend your precious hours doing what will bring out the real you! The brilliant, passionate you that's ready to contribute something meaningful into this world!Soul&nbspwill be released on 19 June, 2020 in the US and in the UK.The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.UK ‘in the relegation&nbspzone’ for economic growth and must change the manager, says TUCThe UK is one of the worst-performing developed economies in the world since the last general election in 2017, new analysis has shown.Annual growth has come in at just 1.3 per cent – less than half the average of 2.7 per cent among members of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), a club of wealthy nations. That put the UK 31st out of 35 OECD nations in the period since Theresa May unexpectedly lost the Conservatives’ parliamentary majority.Almost every OECD nation has outperformed the UK on exports and levels of investment, which have slowed markedly as a result of uncertainty surrounding Brexit.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Trades Union Congress (TUC), which compiled the figures, said a decade of austerity, Brexit mismanagement and a fragile global economy had caused a slump in business confidence.&nbspFrances&nbspO’Grady, the TUC general secretary, said: “The UK economy has fallen into the relegation zone – and you have to blame the manager. title: walking exercise global economy jogging fitness world health organisation
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Fewer sick days and longer working lives would give economic growth a shot in the armThe world economy could be boosted by as much as $100bn&nbsp(£78bn) a year if employers successfully encouraged their staff to meet World Health Organisation guidelines on exercise, according to an analysis of the economic impact of activity.Adding an extra 15 minutes of daily walking, or jogging a steady one kilometre each day, would improve productivity and extend life expectancy - leading to more economic growth, the study by the health insurance group Vitality and the think tank Rand&nbspEurope found.The economic boost would come from lower mortality rates - in other words keeping more people alive, working and contributing to the economy for longer, the study’s authors said, and from employees taking fewer days off sick.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHans Pung, Rand&nbspEurope’s president, said the study highlighted “a significant relationship between inactivity and productivity loss” and should give policymakers and employers “new perspectives on how to enhance the productivity of their populations”.The WHO recommends that all adults should take at least 150 minutes of moderate exercise, or 75 minutes of vigorous exercise, a week. In a study last year it found that around 40 per cent of adults in the United States, 36 per cent in Britain and 14 per cent in China did too little exercise to stay healthy.Created with Sketch. Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.410 Bow and Three Mills, London410 Bow and Three Mills, LondonThe RandVitality study was based in part on data from about 120,000 people across seven countries. It then modelled and projected the potential economic benefits of increased physical activity globally and for 23 inidual countries.It found that if all adults aged between 18 and 64 walked 15 more minutes a day, it could increase world economic output by some $100bn year on year.It also found that physically inactive 40-year-olds could increase their life expectancy, on average, by 3.2 years, by introducing 20 minutes of jogging a day.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: general election uk latest news today live
story: The PM will visit Northern England, Scotland and Northern Ireland as the Chancellor Sajid Javid and Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell battle it out over who is best to run the countrys finances - and who will control the money in your pocket.It comes just hours after the huge news that Labours Tom Watson is quitting politics - as an MP and the partys deputy leader.Follow our live blog below for all the latest General Election  news and Brexit updates.Visas for nurses will be halved in cost and fast-tracked under Tory immigration plans, Boris Johnson announced last night.The new “NHS visa” will be part of his blueprint for a points-based immigration system after Britain leaves the EU # designed to adapt to the changing needs of the UK economy.Under the scheme, the cost of a visa for health professionals would be halved from £ to £, while applicants would be guaranteed a decision within two weeks.JohnMcDonnell’s hard-left plans to splurge a whopping £billion every year could “bankrupt Britain”, experts warned.The Labour plans would cost an eye-watering £, per household, and would send borrowing soaring.The shadow chancellor plans to create a new £bn ‘social transformation fund’ to pour cash into schools, hospitals and care homes over the next five years.Britains oldest Jewish newspaper launched a devastating attack on Jeremy Corbyn # declaring him a “racist” must never be PM.In an unprecedented attack, the Jewish Chronicle ran a front-page piece pleading with non-Jews not to vote Labour.The shattering editorial accused Mr Corbyn of spending his entire career allying himself with anti-Semites and insulting Jews. Top Tories last night branded the Lib Dems’ new Remain Alliance “anti-democratic” – as Labour europhiles raged at being targeted by it.Pro-EU parties launched a bid to stitch up  seats across England and Wales to keep Boris Johnson out of No  and overturn Brexit.The Lib Dems, Greens and Plaid Cymru have agreed to stand aside for each other tactically across the country.They will target  seats in Wales and  in England, including those of top Brexiteers including Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab and environment minister Zac Goldsmith.Boris Johnson has promised to slash the cost of American whiskey immediately after Brexit following secret talks with US officials.The PM said he would remove the EU’s crippling tarfs slapped on American imports after Donald Trump’s trade war with Brussels.Thatll be sure to make fans of Bourbon raise a rye smile#and a glass.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour brexit election nationalisation
story: Households across the UK could suffer average losses of nearly £, each from pensions and savingsLabour’s zealots were to pay below market value for the companies, according to economists.Eventhey paid a fair price, Labour would mortgage the future of younger generations to meet the eye-watering £billion-plus cost of taking the companies back into state ownership.And for what  To suit the ideological posturing of Corbyn and his fellow extremist John McDonnell.It’s not asthe railways or the energy companies would be better run. Just ask anyone old enough to remember British Rail.While dinosaurs Corbyn and McDonnell play fantasy politics, aspirational young working class voters have more realistic priorities. Such as wanting reductions in income tax and stamp duty.There is so much more at stake in this general election than just the threat Labour poses to Brexit.DOES anyone know what Labour’s position on Brexit is Jeremy Corbyn claims to have told his squabbling shadow cabinet to fall in behind him and toe the party line.Whether Corbyn will let the voters know what that agreed position is before the election is another matter.Given Labour fought the last election promising to respect the referendum result and has done everything possible since to thwart it, we doubt it.It is suggested Labour would try to renegotiate with the EU for a closer trading partnership , then hold another referendum.What they would do about the inevitable deadlock is anyone’s guess. Meanwhile, several Labour front-benchers have suggested they would campaign for Remain.One union leader has branded them “ludicrous”. The fudges and fence-sitting may have worked for Corbyn in  but surely it won’t fool voters again. For now though, his indecision is final.NO sooner have doctors pleaded with politicians on all sides not to weaponise the NHS than Labour is caught peddling yet more health lies.Wrong. title: john legend politically correct airbrushing
story: Why  Because last year, the original song was banned by a radio station in the US state of Ohio after “listeners”complained that it’s a socially unacceptable ditty promoting coercive behaviour.So it’s now been fed in to the #MeToo sausage machine and emerged as a smooth cylinder of PC compliance where, among other lyric changes, Legend and his duet partner Kelly Clarkson substitute “Say, what’s in this drink  ” for “If I have one more drink  ”.According to the songwriter Frank Loesser’s son John: “It was a flirtatious, wonderful, sexy number between two people who like each other. It really wasn’t anything but that.”But at the time of the ban, Cleveland Rape Crisis Center president and CEO Sondra Miller said: “It really pushed the line of consent.The character in the song is saying ‘no’, and they’re saying, ‘Well, does no really mean yes ’. “What we know is consent is ‘yes’ andyou get a ‘no’, it means ‘no’ and you should stop right there.”Let’s hope she’s never listening to the radio when Fire by The Pointer Sisters comes on. “You’re pullin’ me close, I just say no, I say I don’t like it, but you know I’m a liar.”Then, next verse: “You’re takin’ me home, you say you want to stay, I say I want to be alone . . . but you know I’m a liar.”Is she a “liar” who’s simply pretending she doesn’t have the hots for him when secretly she does  Or is she a victim being coerced into thinking that about herself by a controlling lover Discuss. While we still can. Or what about the Rolling Stones classic Under My Thumb, about a girl “who once pushed me around” but now, “It’s a squirmin’ dog who’s just had her day, Under my thumb, A girl who has just changed her ways” Far better, surely, to put it all out there so our kids can learn the vital le skill of rational and informed debate.A rock ’n’ roll twist, perhaps, on the premise of Shakespeare’s The Taming Of The Shrew, in which Petruchio uses a number of tactics to bring his we Katherina to heel — or is that now banned too In today’s “attention economy”, keyboard warriors desperate to be heard appear to be scouring the airwaves for even the merest whf of potential offence and, worse still, some are seeing their confected high dudgeon rewarded with a ban.And it’s not just the music industry having its chain yanked. This week it emerged that several theatres will be dropping the traditional “Ladies and gentlemen, please take your seats,” instruction to avoid offending any transgender customers.Sigh. Of all the things in the world to truly feel offended by, is this really a priority  Even Barack Obama, the darling of the liberal classes, feels that the call-out culture sometimes goes too far.“The world is messy. There are ambiguities,” said the former US President during a recent interview about youth activism. This idea of purity and you’re never compromised and you’re always politically ‘woke’ and all that stuff . . . you should get over that quickly.”He went on to address the “cancel culture” on social media where someone who has said or done something to which others object is immediately shut down in a wave of judgmental condemnation.“That’s not activism. That’s not bringing about change,” he added. “If all you’re doing is casting stones, you’re probably not going to get that far. That’s easy to do.”Hear hear. So, by all means, write new songs through the prism of #MeTooyou so wish. But banning or airbrushing the classics to suit modern sensitivitiesdoes us all a disservice.Far better, surely, to put it all out there so our kids can learn the vital le skill of rational and informed debate.“Jo Swinson: Britain’s Next Prime Minister”is the headline on just one of the many missives – a six-page, A booklet.Under Electoral Commission rules, each party can spend up to £, for each constituency it contests.She must be nearing that on my house alone.IRON Maiden frontman Bruce Dickinson has split from we Paddy after  years and moved in with a “superfan”.Bruce, , who has an estimated fortune of £million, is now shacked up in Paris with Leana Dolci, who has followed his band for ten years and recently attended a heavy-metal festival in a T-shirt that read: “I fancy the lead singer.” Subtle.When plugging his autobiography a couple of years ago, Bruce told an interviewer he tried to keep his private le out of the public gaze.“So I made the decision that, in amongst not being horrid to people . . . I also don’t want to tell confidences about other people’s lives,” he said.Bruce can only hope his estranged we shares the same view.THIS Halloween, famous fancy dress supplier Smfys boasted on its website, “Looking hot has never been so easy,” while offering a range of saucy outfits from devil cheerleader to Miss Whiplash and sexy skeleton.In my twenties, it was an old bedsheet with a couple of eye-holes. But there are a few purists out there who eschew the sexy-not-scary look and embrace the original Halloween’s wholly spooky, otherworldly intentions.Believe it or not, this hideous creature is model Heidi Klum arriving at her own Halloween party in New York . . . with all the confidence of a woman who knows full well that, next morning, she s to being an effortlessly sexy beauty with or without sartorial assistance.REMEMBER James Stunt When he was married to Bernie Ecclestone’s daughter Petra, he used a fleet of luxury cars to make ostentatiously expensive purchases at ious designer stores and art galleries.But Stunt has insisted he would never deceive the Prince of Wales because, “he’s a great man. I consider him to be a friend”.Whether the feeling is mutual one can only speculate. But something tells me Mr Stunt is about to be royally ghosted.THE imagined target voter for the Tories in the General Election is “Workington Man”.He joins Tony Blair’s “Mondeo Man” , David Cameron’s “Holby City Woman”and Margaret Thatcher’s “Essex Man” as a confection of election strategists, who would like us all to think they’re experts but, in truth, know as much as the rest of usabout what the outcome will be.Many moons ago, when I worked for a dferent newspaper, staff were taken on a drink think-tank where a “creative” from a top ad agency wielded a cardboard cutout of “Swindon Woman” who he’d laughably concluded was our typical reader.There was much derision all round, particularly when she disappeared and was later found being cuddled in the bed of a comatose sports reporter.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc public broadcaster pays megabucks
story: Anyone who realised that the organisation for which they work is awash with cash would do the same.When Ahmed realised that she was receiving only £ for presenting her -minute long BBC programme when Jeremy Vine was being paid £, for his show of the same , she thought, not unreasonably, “I want a bit of that”.Like any other employee, she has every right to use the employment tribunal system to settle grievances. Yet the way Ahmed’s case has been pumped up as a great cause celebre for women is frankly ridiculous.The real scandal is not that a highly paid female BBC presenter has been paid less than a male one. It is that the BBC is lavishing such fat pay on any of them while pleading poverty and ending free TV licences for people over .Ahmed’s case for equal pay is very weak. It is based on the argument that presenting Newswatch — which holds BBC’s news programmes to account — is of equal value to presenting Vine’s old show, Points Of View, which invited comments from the public on a wide iety of BBC programmes.The BBC claims the disparity is down to the fact that Points Of View is classied as entertainment while Newswatch comes under news.  Surely a more direct comparison would be between what Ahmed is paid and what her male predecessor, Raymond Snoddy, was paid.She received the same as he did. How is that gender discrimination   But while the BBC might have a strong defence in Ahmed’s case, it doesn’t endear the corporation to me.Every time the BBC Charter comes up for renewal, it poses as a terribly worthy public ­service broadcaster putting out serious, educational programmes no commercial broadcaster would touch.Unless the Government allows it to jack up the licence fee, it argues, it will mean no more David Attenborough, no more news correspondents in Mogadishu.Then, as soon as the BBC Charter is renewed, it goes back to pumping out the same old entertainment shows, many of them indistinguishable from commercial TV.A genuine public service broadcaster would not pay Gary Lineker £.million a year, Graham Norton £,or Huw Edwards £,.Compared with the fattest of BBC fat cats, Samira Ahmed might well feel undervalued. Yet earning £ for presenting a -minute programme would be a dream for many TV licence-payers, many of whom do not even earn that amount of money in a week.The BBC is merciless in its efforts to collect what is really a tax on TV ownership. Unlike other unpaid utility bills, failing to buy a TV licence is a criminal offence, leading to low-paid people struggling with finances being dragged through the courts.Last year, , people were prosecuted for non-payment. By the way,  per cent of them were women — possibly because they were more likely to be at home during the day when TV licence enforcement officers tend to call. That is the real gender unfairness, not highly paid female BBC presenters receiving less money than male presenters.Ahmed’s case has highlighted the old boys’ world from which the BBC hires its presenters.  Vine, she claims, was “gted” his Radio  show without any proper recruitment process. BBC management then allowed his agent to jack up his salary.The BBC seems to see itself as immune from the pay restraint where in the public sector. When David Cameron became Prime Minister, he said any public body would need an extremely good excuse to pay anyone more than the £, a year he then earned.Yet the BBC’s accounts for   show it paid  “on-air talent” salaries in excess of this figure.  While there have been token reductions for some male ­presenters, such as the now- retired John Humphrys, many have seen salary increases.High pay doesn’t end with the presenters. There were also  BBC managers and executives who were paid more than the PM last year.  If the BBC wants to justy the TV licence, it needs to be cutting excessive pay among its board and ­presenters.If it wants to be a commercial station, on the other hand, it should give up the licence fee and find funding from subscriptions and ­advertising.  Then it wouldn’t be our business how much its executives and presenters were paid because their salaries would come out of the pockets only of people who chose to subscribe to its programmes.This is particularly important now, in the week that both Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn have vowed to sort out the threat of over-s losing their licence fee exemption.As it becomes an urgent election issue, the worst look for the BBC is to be seen throwing money at presenters rather than the people it needs most — its loyal viewers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: And it wasn’t just because one of Gordon Brown’s closest aides, Ian Austin, quit the ­Labour Party and urged people to vote for Boris Johnson, on the grounds that Jeremy ­Corbyn was unfit to lead the country.Or because Labour’s deputy leader, Tom Watson, finally gave up the fight against the hardliners who have captured his party, abandoning his ­constituencyto the Corbynites and launching a new career as a health campaigner.It was because Sajid Javid and John McDonnell, the Chancellor and Shadow Chancellor, set out spending plans that presented the country with two very dferent versions of Britain’s financial future — and showed that the choice facing voters in a month’s time goes far beyond Brexit.In his speech in Manchester, Javid officially consigned austerity firmly to the dustbin.In its place were hard hat and hi-vis.By splitting off day-to-day spending from infrastructure, he not only gave himself more room for spending on the NHS and other public services .He signalled that he and PM Boris want to get Britain building.The Chancellor’s plan is a bold one. It doesn’t just signal an end to austerity but an end to decades in which governments of all parties have spent much less than similar countries on maintaining the fabric of the nation.Under Javid’s plan, this kind of investment by the Government would increase by roughly  per cent — taking us back to levels not seen consistently since the s.He argues that with borrowing costs at their lowest for decades, and the country’s accounts finally repaired after the  crash, there is room for this kind of spending.We are practically at the point, he says, where people are paying Britain for the privilege of lending us money.Soyou can put that cash towards something that gets a decent , you’re quids in.This isn’t, he insists, an indiscriminate splurge. Instead, it is investments that will pay for themselves by making Britain richer in the long run — more schools, faster broadband, better roads and railways.In the international context, this isn’t actually revolutionary.As mentioned above, most other countries our size spend much more than we do on this kind of thing.But it’s very definitely a break with the existing orthodoxy — and with the focus over recent years on getting debt down as soon as possible.For it to have the impact he hopes for, the Chancellor will need to juggle this new spending with keeping firm control over the day-to-day side of the balance sheet.He will also have to make sure that any public spending is accompanied by a matching surge in private investment — not just in new roads, railways and power stations, but businesses and machinery, too.And he will need to maintain a laser-like focus on ensuring we are picking the best projects — and running them properly.Not spending for the sake of it, just because Whitehall has set the investment target at a particular level.No one wants to go back to the Gordon Brown days of forking out billions without much of a care as to whether the benefits outweighed costs.No one, that is, except John McDonnell — only he wants to go way, way further.Because just after Javid sat down in Manchester, his Labour opposite number got to his feet in Liverpool to outline Labour’s own fiscal framework. On the face of it, McDonnell’s language about boosting infrastructure spending sounds pretty similar to Javid’s.Both were talking about investing for the future, about borrowing now to profit later.Both had their parties’ election slogans on the podium in front of them and the wall behind them, and were wearing ties that carefully matched the Tory blue and Labour red of the backdrop.But when you look at the detail, this isn’t a case of Spendin’ Saj vs Lavish Labour. It is more like the dference between being offered a chocolate bar — and stuffing your face with half a dozen Yorkies.The Tories are promising to spend roughly £billion extra on infrastructure over the next five years. But Javid insists that they will turn off the taps the moment the repayment costs get too high.Labour are up to £billion and counting. And that is without adding on the extra upfront borrowing involved in Labour’s renationalisation plans, which our think-tank estimates at £billion at least.Or the tens of billions that will be loaned to homeowners to pay for insulation, or borrowed from the private sector to build new state-owned wind farms.The amounts that Javid and McDonnell are talking about are both huge numbers.But to simply, the dference between them is the dference between spending more money, and spending all the money.And it also sets out the iding line that the Tories will surelyto throughout this campaign.But we want to spend what we can afford.Labour want to spend what we can’t.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: patrick frazee last words fiance trial
story: The apparent tragic final words of Ky Berreth, , were revealed at the highly publicized murder trial of her partner Patrick Frazee.Suspected killer Frazee, , is accused of battering the mother of his young daughter to death in their home in Woodland Park, Colorado, on Thanksgiving last year.He then manipulated mistress Krystal Lee - who aborted a baby he had fathered - to help dispose of Berreths mutilated body, she claims.Idaho-born nurse Lee took to the witness stand at the Teller County courthouse on Wednesday to make a series of harrowing allegations against her former lover, the Denver Post reports.Lee, who turned state witness after agreeing a plea deal with prosecutors in February, claims she spent  hours scrubbing the blood-stained murder scene at Frazees home - after he called her to say he had a mess to clean up.She claims that when she arrived at Frazees condo on Thanksgiving , she was presented with a horror show - including dried blood on the walls and bloody footprints all over the floors.Lee said: I didn’t know that he was capable of that.“I didn’t know that he was capable of what happened, and I didn’t do anything to stop it.”During the frantic effort to destroy evidence, Frazee told her that his blindfolded fiances desperate final words as he beat her to death were: Please stop, Lee claimed.Lee, whod had a -year affair with Frazee, has pleaded guilty to evidence tampering for moving Berreths cell phone.She claimed to have helped Frazee move a container that had Berreths body inside and burned it to cover their tracks.No remains have been found by police despite several searches.Lee said she also grabbed several blood-spattered items from Berreths home to be burned.Among the items were a stuffed animal, childrens building blocks and what she thought was a Bible.She also testied that Frazee and Berreths baby daughter was in the home when the mother was bludgeoned to death.Lee alleges that she was brainwashed into helping her lover murder Berreth - after Frazee claimed she was abusive to their little girl.Lee said: He said his little girl was being abused.I know it was wrong, but I didn’t know what to do and I didn’t make the right decisions.Such was her devotion to helping Frazee take care of the problem of his fiance that she carried a weapon with her every time she saw Berreth, Lee claimed.The pair even plotted poisoning Berreths caramel macchiato coffee, Lee alleged.But her doubts about Frazees allegations against his fiance were raised when she saw him scolding his daughter.Lee said:  “That’s when I had the thought that Ky probably wasn’t doing anything wrong.“She just couldn’t do anything right.”After the alleged murder, Frazees mistress took Berreths phone from the condo and drove it to Idaho at his request to make it look like Berreth had left the state, Lee claimed.She was later found by law enforcement and initially lied to the FBI before eventually agreeing to cooperate.Prosecutors have not offered a motive for Frazee to kill Berreth, but her parents argue in a wrongful death lawsuit that they believe he wanted full custody of the couples daughter.Frazee would be sentenced to le in prison without parolehe is convicted of first-degree murder - title: labours john mcdonnells spending promises would be laughable if they were not so scary
story: Labour’s John McDonnell promised an extra £billion of borrowing for “social transformation”, on top of £billion already announced for “green” projects, on top of plans to renationalise swathes of industry, which are tipped to cost at least £billion.You might wonder how all this uncosted magic money will be paid for.Don’t worry, says McDonnell. The billions for renationalisation wouldn’t really count as a debt but as “assets”.For the other £billion he plans to sting the rich and grab £billion worth of shares from businesses.It’s fantasy economics. Wealthy job-creators would not stick around to be fleeced.It would be ordinary earners getting hit by higher taxes, higher prices, lower salaries and lost jobs.Experts warn McDonnell could bankrupt Britain and saddle the country with ballooning debt for generations.Labour’s bribes would be the most expensive “free money” ever offered.TOM Watson cravenly ducked the election campaign before his Leave-voting constituents could kick him out for his Brexit-blocking betrayal.It says a lot about the rancid state of Labour under Jeremy Corbyn that a man as vindictive and unprincipled as Watson is being painted as its moderate voice and a bulwark against the extremists who have hijacked it.In fact, Ian Austin is that voice — a proud Labour man who had the courage to call out “poisonous” Corbyn.Watson, the enemy of press freedom, who should have resigned for his part in the hounding of innocent Tories on the flimsy word of a lying paedophile, could have walked out on Corbyn three years ago but propped him up instead.Now he leaves with a whimper.Good riddance.IT has been madness to turn away doctors and nurses and key skilled workers because they come from outside the EU.Control of our borders does not mean shutting our doors to migrants.A flexible, points-based system, with fast-tracking for NHS workers, means welcoming the best talent from around the world when and where we need it.WHY would any Tories defend wannabe MP Nick Conrad, who once said women should “keep their knickers on” to avoid rape Thank goodness he’s gone. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: i turned down love island
story: Did I want to trade my boyfriend of eight years for a sunshine holiday, fame and the chance to make millions On Thursday a producer at ITV rang, wanting to knowI was a single and b interested in appearing in the next series of Love Island.AndI wasnt single but was interested, would I dump my boyfriend, Alex, for the opportunity.The producer told me that of the , applicants they get every year - more than apply to Oxbridge - they look for someone with a bit of something dferent. First we had Camilla, who worked in landmine disposal, then it was Dr Alex, the NHS doctor and this year we had “scientist” Yewande. I think what the producer was trying to tell me was that they wanted someone not quite as fit as the rest of them, but a bit smarter. No offence. It was a flattering call, I won’t lie to you ... but one that seemed about as unlikely to me as my being accepted onto the space programme. I am so not Love Island - or the face of the inevitable Missguided deal every female Islander leaves with.Despite being a slim , young, blonde woman, I cannot imagine anywhere I’d feel less at home than in the Love Island villa, where the women wear next to nothing and flaunt theirsurgically enhanced bodies.I rarely wear makeup, live in scruffy clothes and hardly ever brush my hair.The closest I’ve ever got to plastic surgery was with a “lip plumping” lip gloss - andI so much as tried to wear a pair of high heels near the pool I’d inevitably slip and break my neck.EvenI survived that, I don’t know how I’d feel about opening myself up to the show’s . million nightly viewers.The producer told me they look for a bit of something dferent. I’m a lot of something dferent and I don’t think I’d ever be strong enough to deal with the publics critical eye.The reason Love Island is so enjoyable to watch is because the contestants are all SO perfect - it’s like playing The Sims. People troll the contestants on the logic that it’s okay because they are too good looking to care. Its almost like they’re their own caricatures - they’re not real . This year, Harley Brash, , was trending on Twitter, with people mocking her mouth and lips Tragic Love Island star Sophie Gradon called for action to stop trolls who drive people to suicide weeks before she took her own le.Sophie, , told a cyber bullying conference in March she “descended into a dark place” after the ITV show because of vicious online abuse.And Zara Holland admitted she too struggled with her mental health and warned wannabe contestants: “You will be haunted by this for the rest of your le.”Im not perfect - and Id be an easy target with my stomach rolls and heat rash.I think I’d make it all too real. And this is why, I suspect, the show will never change. In order to give it the ersity it so desperately needs there will first to be a woman that doesn’t look as good in a bikini as the others, a man who’s balding, someone in a wheelchair, a person with a scar... And who wants be the first to make that change  At the end of the day, it’s a looks-based show. And I got picked last for sports teams enough times to know the humiliation of not being chosen. That’s not something I want to relive in front of the ruthless British public. And then of course there’s the fact that Love Island changes your le. If they like you, that’s any chance of a normal le out the windowandthey hate you, well, that’s your whole le out the window. The aftercarefor contestants on the show is something that’s been well documented, with both Sophie Gradon and Mike Thalassitis having subsequently taken their own lives.I got the call that so many people want to get - and I had to turn it down.Not just because of my very long term relationship, or because I’m too sensitive to face thejudgement of the nation, or that I’d be the only one to have tummy rolls , or that it would turn my le as I know it on it’s head. I turned it down because I know that all that glitters is most certainly not gold, and no amount of Range Rover Sports would see me sell my soul to this particular devil. That and the fact that I honestly don’t know how I’d be able to not throw someone in the pool for asking: “what’s Brexit   ” as Hayley Hughes famously did in Series . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lib dem remain election pact
story: Pro-EU parties launched a bid to stitch up  seats across England and Wales to keep Boris Johnson out of No  and overturn Brexit.The Lib Dems, Greens and Plaid Cymru have agreed to stand aside for each other tactically across the country.They will target  seats in Wales and  in England, including those of top Brexiteers including Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab and environment minister Zac Goldsmith.The alliance, dubbed Unite to Remain, has said it believes  of those are “highly winnable” from both the Tories and Labour.Critics predicted it will have a limited impact, pointing out the Lib Dems are on course to win a third of the constituencies involved anyway.The plot was slammed by top Conservatives who said voters would be “angry” at being deprived of a genuine choice in those seats affected.Senior Tory Nigel Evans said: “It’s incredible, but then the election is all about stopping Brexit and they’re throwing everything  to the wolves in order to do that. It’s not about their beliefs.“If I was a Lib Dem in an area that just lost their candidate, or a Green that’s just lost their right to vote for their party, they may feel angry.“I call it a rotten Remainer alliance. Its anti-democratic and it’s against what the British people voted for.“I don’t think the Lib Dems are going to do as well as they think because there are a lot of democrats out there.”Mr Evans added that Brexit Party candidates should “wake up” and “pull the plug” in seats where the Tories are vulnerable or there will be a “heavy price”.The Remain Alliance also ran into fierce criticism from Labour candidates, who pointed out several of the seats being targeted are held by strong second referendum campaigners.Senior Labour politician Wes Streeting fumed: “A ‘Remain Alliance’ that targets Labour people with impeccable pro-European credentials is nothing of the sort.”The group said it had invited Jeremy Corbyn to take part but was rebuffed by members of his frontbench team.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said: “We will never enter pact, coalitions, or deals like that. Ever“I’d just say this to those Greens and others who are getting into bed with the Lib Dems – I remember what the Lib Dems did when they were in government.”She said: “With a single Remain candidate in each of these seats, we can deliver a greater number of MPs into parliament.“This is our opportunity to tip the balance of power away from the two largest parties and into the progressive Remain alliance.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thousands ice eggs cover beach finland
story: The egg-shaped balls of ice have been pictured covering the entire Scandinavian beach on Hailuoto Island in the Gulf of Bothnia.The extraordinary sight was captured by amateur photographer Risto Mattila who came across the beach.Experts say it is caused by a rare process in which small pieces of ice are rolled over by wind and water.Risto, from nearby Oulu, told the BBC he had never witnessed anything like it.He said: I was with my we at Marjaniemi beach. The weather was sunny, about -Cand it was quite a windy day.There we found this amazing phenomenon. There was snow and ice eggs along the beach near the water line.He said the balls of ice extended over a ft area with some as big as footballs.He added: That was an amazing view. I have never seen anything like this during  years living in the vicinitySince I had a camera with me I decided to preserve this unusual sight for posterity.A shallow and slightly sloping sandy beach with calm waves and possibly a light swell is the perfect setting for the ice eggs to form.The ice begins to colect and form a core as the swell moves it along the beach, forward and back.A small ball surface gets wet, freezes and becomes bigger and bigger as it rolls back and forth.Dr James Carter, professor of geography-geology at Illinois State University, said Autumn is the perfect time to see the phenomenon as this is when ice starts to form on the surface of water, creating a form of slush when moved by waves.Similar sights have been reported before, including in Russia and on Lake Michigan near Chicago.In  residents of Nyda in Siberia found giant balls of ice and snow covering an kmstretch of coastline.They ranged from the size of a tennis ball to almost macross.A similar phenomenon known as ice pancakes occurs in the UK.The phenomenon on the River Helmsdale was such a spectacle that it prompted a group of binmen to pull over and take in the mesmerising view.Amateur photographer Daniel Norrie, , took photos and video of the occurrence — caused when pieces of ice knock together and create circular shapes, known as ice pancakes.

story: NewsDawn Butler first major candidate to replace Tom Watson as Labour Deputy LeaderTom Watson announced on Wednesday evening that he was stepping down as an MP and quitting frontline politics after  years.ShareByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  NOV NewsDawn Butler is a close ally of Jeremy Corbyn "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Dawn Butler is the first major candidate to announce she wants replace Tom Watson as Labour Deputy Leader after he sensationally quit onTom Watson announced on Wednesday evening that he was stepping down as an MP and quitting frontline politics after  years.In contrast with Mr Watson, Dawn Butler has been a loyal ally to her fellow London MP Jeremy Corbyn .Speaking to Bloomberg TV, Ms Butler said: Iaposve thought very carefully about who should replace Tom and after giving it some thought, I will be throwing my hat in the ring. The -year-old Londoner is looking to position herself as pro-Corbyn and a voice for minority groups at the top of the party in the upcoming deputy leadership contest.    I think Iaposve got a track record of countering, holding people to account around race, equality and justice, she said. Iaposve got a track record of being very supportive to our leader Jeremy Corbyn and ensuring the Labour Party is on the front foot. There are structural barriers that hold people back. I want to as deputy leader change all of that, change the way the country is currently developing, change the way weaposre seeing hate overcome hope, change the script on all of that. She sparked controversy at last yearaposs Labour conference when she praised the former Militant-led Liverpool council in the s for setting budgets in excess of the limits imposed by Westminster. Ms Butler told delegates it was better to break the law than break the poor.    Other possible candidates include Laura Pidcock, shadow employment rights secretary, is tipped to get the backing of major union Unite and would be a popular figure for the left of the party. While Rebecca Long-Bailey, shadow business secretary, has been repeatedly put forward by the leadership including shadow chancellor John McDonnell. Ms Long-Bailey has been mentioned publicly as a potential future leader and the high-profile figure revealed a slick video and personal logo on social media this week, a move interpreted internally as an early leadership bid. There is speculation that other high profile politicians such as shadow education secretary Angela Rayner and shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry may swerve the race to concentrate on going for the leadership when Jeremy Corbyn stands down. Yesterday Mr Corbyn said that would be in the long distant future but it is widely agreed he will have to goLabour do badly at the election and Shadow chancellor and ally John McDonnell has repeatedly insisted that the next Labour leader should be a woman. title: jeremy corbyn live apollo sums
story: NewsAnalysisJeremy Corbyn does Live at the Apollo - and it sums up his whole general election campaignNot the Hammersmith Apollo on BBC Two, but the Manchester Apollo - and a crowd of hundreds of cheering Labour backers. Dan Bloom saw a show that was well-worn but told from the heartShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsAnalysis "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailManchestEEER! bellowed Angela Rayner. It’s an absolute pleasure to be LIVE AT THE APOLLO! Sure, there was no Michael McIntyre. No primetime TV audience. The warm-up act was the Labour prospective parliamentary candidate for West Derby. And the jokes werenapost that funny... ... Actually, maybe it was a bit like Live at the Apollo after all. Jeremy Corbynaposs gigs - sorry, rallies - have always felt as much like crowd-participation live drama as a political event. And Thursday nightaposs, at Manchesteraposs Apollo, showed he has no plan to reinvent the wheel heaposs rolled on since gaining those seats in .    The Labour activists cheered, chanted, stood and waved placards emblazoned itaposs time for real change as Labouraposs leader worked the crowd for  minutes. Little to none of it was aposnewsapos in the traditional sense. Sure, there were plenty of policies, but all announced before, for anyone who bothers to get on Google. The thing is - and we in Westminster do forget this - to this crowd of ultra-faithful it doesnapost matter a jot. The cut-and-thrust of the campaign matters less than the feeling of being part of a spectacle, a movement. They chanted not! for! sale! - the mantra of the  campaign - as he warned of an NHS sell-out to Donald Trump.    They booed the Lib Dems, who leapt on the event with a blazing ad van declaring Only Lib Dems will stop Brexit. They laughed as Corbyn boasted of his £m in small donations: I was going to call all my billionaire friends until I realised I didn’t have any! And one shouted w***er! as Corbyn told how Boris Johnson would crash Britain out of the EU with no deal. Itaposs not pantomime season yet! Corbyn cried, the stage lightbulbs blazing behind him. Agree with any of it or none, anyone can see how the atmosphere jars with images of Boris Johnson. story: NewsLabour vows to end UK austerity and slams puny Tory pledgesShadow Chancellor John McDonnell, of the Labour Party, told voters in Liverpool that the Conservatives "treat us all with contempt"ShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV NewsShadow Chancellor John McDonnell, of the Labour Party, delivers a key speech "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters.
