title: vote-now-name-east-lothians-new-town
story: Thousands of homes are to be built on the site of the former Blindwells opencast coal mine between Tranent and Longniddry.After inviting school pupils to suggest possible names for the new town, East Lothian Council put together a shortlist.Five of the "most popular and suitable" names submitted by schools were selected by a  of councillors and council officials: Charlestoun, Hattonfield, Hopetoun, Muirdale and Nethermuir.The council had urged schools to come up with a "fresh, new name" for the new town and had told them that it did not feel that officially naming the town Blindwells, with its connections to the sites mining past, "fits with all the great new facilities that are going to be in the new town".This caused upset in some quarters that the countys industrial heritage was being ignored.And following public pleas, including a written submission to the council chief executive from Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council, the name Blindwells was added to the shortlist in the wake of, said the local authority, ldquorepresentations.At a meeting of councillors on Tuesday, that decision was welcomed.Councillor Lachlan Bruce said: ldquoI welcome the inclusion of Blindwells. It is something I have been hearing about constantly from local residents.Fellow councillor Neil Gilbert added: ldquoIt is good news Blindwells is considered.Planning permission for the first , houses at the site has already been granted and the first homes are expected to be built next year.The public consultation on the name for East Lothianrsquos new town has now opened - with anyone who logs on to the councils consultation hub able to vote for their favourite out of the six shortlisted.Councillor Willie Innes, the council leader, said: "This is a truly exciting opportunity to come up with a name for this town."We wanted all school pupils in East Lothian to be involved as they are the generation who will be most likely to be living and working in this new settlement."We are very grateful to our schools for their deliberations and responses. As there has been a lot of public interest in what the new town will be called, we wanted to give the public the chance to vote on the final shortlist.Votes can be cast until December  here.

title: tributes-paid-well-known-hairdresser-melvin-wood
story: The owner of that salon, Melvin Wood, passed away suddenly on holiday in Tenere on September , aged . He succumbed toheart failure.His we Lorna said: ldquoWe were in our favourite hotel and were very happy and relaxed.ldquoIt was very sudden and unexpected but he didnrsquot suffer and his final memories were happy ones.Melvin made North Berwick his family home and workplace and was well known as a larger-than-le character in the community.He was born on September , , in Edinburgh. His father John was a director at Lyon  Turnbull, auctioneers and valuators on George Street. His mother Sybil was a well-known character in her own right, known by many as Sybs, Squibs and Grandma Swag.Melvin attended Melville College but left at the age of  as school wasnrsquot for him. He was more interested in his mumrsquos Vogue magazines.He got his first job soon after at His Hair, which started his love of hairdressing. He moved onto Charlie Miller, where he didnrsquot get off to the best start: Charlie told his father that Melvin would be better off working as a plumber.But Charlie saw Melvinrsquos passion and decided thathe wanted to be a hairdresser he should go train with the best, so in the early s he supported Melvin so he could go to London and train at Vidal Sassoon.During his time in London he got the opportunity to work on high-profile projects such as wigs for singer Diana Ross. Other famous clients included La Toya Jackson, Dustin Hoffman and Shirley Bassey, who famously threw a shoe at him.In  he entered the first Scottish Wella Vogue competition, winning with his creation of tartan hair. He was featured in the national and international press, on national TV, and even appeared in Rolling Stone and Playboy magazines.He was asked to go to America with Vidal Sassoon but he wanted to come home so moved back to Edinburgh. With the support of his family he opened Melvin  Friends in November  on the cityrsquos Castle Street.His philosophy was always lsquoHairdressing Naturallyrsquo and he believed in using biodegradable products not tested on animals.The business expanded and he opened salons in many places including Alnwick, Peebles and several in and around Edinburgh. He even opened a salon in the Sheraton Hotel.In , Melvin became the proud father of Oliver, who filled the air with fun and laughter, having many happy times growing up.In , Melvin met Lorna through a mutual friend. They set up home together, moving near to Haddington in  and were married in , then moving the business to North Berwick in .In , their family grew with the birth of Hannah.Melvin worked in the salon in North Berwick for  years, where he had a loyal following.Many local youngsters had their first jobs in the salon and Melvin taught them as a qualied SVQ mentor and a master hairdresser in the Hairdressers Council. When North Berwick High School had a hair training salon, he held sessions on the basics of hairdressing.Many stories could be told about his days in the salon, like when golfrsquos The Open Championship was held and top player Vijay Singh came in for a cut.Melvin, not being a golfer, did not know who he was, but they got chatting and Vijay said he was here for golf, so Melvin very kindly recommended some of the courses his customers had told him about!During the early days, Melvin could be found at the townrsquos Nether Abbey Hotel sometimes as a customer but sometimes as the chef as he had a great love for cooking.Many happy times were spent there and many parties were had, where Melvin was given access to the kitchens and, along with friends, did the catering.For his th birthday, he cooked for  friends.He was also famous every year for his barbecues held at the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune during its airshow.Melvin liked people to appreciate his food he would make lunch for the girls who worked in the salon, just liking to see them eat and enjoy. He taught Hannah to cook and was so proud of what she produced in the kitchen.Added his we: ldquoMelvin was a great dad, he was fun and made sure he did fun things with his children. He was so proud of me and them, and would brag about what they had achieved, often embellishing the stories.ldquoHe was a wonderful, loving husband who really looked after me.ldquoHe grabbed le with a passion and helived every day to the full, which is a great comfort. I am so grateful to have been able to spend the last  years with him. Although he will begreatly missed, he will never be forgotten.Judy Lockhart, North Berwick Community Council chairwoman, said: ldquoNorth Berwick Community Council was extremely saddened to hear of the recent and untimely passing of Melvin Wood of Melvin  Friends.ldquoMelvin was one of North Berwickrsquos most loved characters. As well as being a superb hairdresser, he had a larger-than-le personality and was also a very talented cook.ldquoMelvin famously hosted an annual barbecue on the day of the airshow which was the calender invite of the year for many.ldquoYou could never fail to smile when in the company of Melvin and he will be sorely missed.A celebration-of-le party is being organised by his family, to be held in January.

title: meet-world-champion-josh-taylor
story: All are welcome to go along to the pub from pm till late and show Josh their support.Diane Taylor, Joshrsquos mum, said: ldquoJosh will be bringing his trophies and belts along to the Gothenburg to see everybody. Itrsquos really a chance for him to thank everyone for all their support.ldquoI think it will be really busy so we canrsquot guarantee everyone will get in but we just feel that because he has that many supporters we didnrsquot want to put a number on it by making it ticketed or anything.Business owner Michelle Wilson said: ldquoWersquore really excited to have a meet and greet with Josh on Saturday in the pub to celebrate his win.ldquoItrsquos great for the locals to come along and be able to see Josh.ldquoThe whole of Prestonpans is behind him so wersquore expecting a big turnout. title: sir-cliff-star-tranents-fraser-centre
story: Catherine Scott, from Haddington, has been a huge Clf Richard fan since  and met her idol for the first time on holiday at his vineyard a few years ago.Catherine purchased a Star of The Fraser Centre for Sir Clf, a fundraising item for the new community hub opening in Tranent, in order to show her admiration for him while supporting the centre.A repeat visit to the vineyard this year led to a ldquomagical meeting when Catherine was able to present Sir Clf with his star.Catherine said: ldquoIt was magical to meet him and he was very pleased with the plaque for the star.ldquoIt is my way of showing my admiration for him and his faith whilst helping a local charity I support.ldquoHe was really pleased with the star and also signed a Fraser Centre shirt to be auctioned off at a later event for the trust.The Stars of The Fraser Centre are engraved stars which are part of the fundraising for the new community hub in Tranent for learning, development, arts and entertainment.The stars are available for anyone to purchase and can contain a name or short message ndash they will all be on display in the completed building.Meanwhile, the long-awaited re-opening of The Fraser Centre will take place next Saturday .The new community centre in the heart of Tranent has been completed on budget at pound. million.It will host a cafe, activity rooms, meeting rooms and offices which are available for rent.A -seat cinema will also open in the centre next year.For its first event, the centre has partnered with MF Funeral Services to host the annual Macmillan Cancer Support coffee morning, .am-.pm. Entry is poundand includes a cake, sandwich and drink, with funds going to the charity.The official Fraser Centre open day then follows between pm and pm. All are welcome to this free event to see how the old picture house has been rebuilt and find out about the new centre.Family entertainment is provided by childrenrsquos entertainer Gladys Chucklebutty. East Lothian Play Association are also providing Loose Parts Play, which encourages children to get creative and play with materials which might otherwise go to landfill. There are also family arts and crafts, including mask making, plus music provided by Radio Saltire.Following this, the cafe will be open part-time until next year, when it opens full-time.The Fraser Centre Community Trust was formed in  and aims to provide a learning, development, arts and entertainment centre in Tranent.David Orr, The Fraser Centre project and development manager, said: ldquoWe are delighted to have a day full of family entertainment to open the new centre and look forward to opening our doors and showing people inside the new building.ldquoItrsquos been such an exciting project in Tranent.ldquoPeople have been able to see the progress of the building and wersquore looking forward to opening.ldquoPlease check our Facebook and Twitter pages and our website for our latest news and updates.At Farsquoside Area Partnershiprsquos annual public meeting, Mr Orr also announced that the centre would take nominations from the public of groups in the Farsquoside area which could be gted access to the centre free of charge.Farsquoside Area Partnership and The Fraser Centre Community Trust have agreed that there will be an application process in which eligible groups can be nominated for free use of space in the centre.Public voting will then take place on which groups should be approved.

title: fore-160-golf-balls-washed-beach
story: A well-known professor was surprised to find more than  golf balls on the beach at Musselburgh, near the mouth of the River Esk, on October  following torrential rain on the Saturday.Roger Crofts CBE, founder chief executive of Scottish Natural Heritage and a director of the Esk Valley Trust, found about  golf balls amongst other debris, such as tree branches and plastics, as he walked his dogs along Fisherrow Sands.He reckoned the balls had been lost over the years by golfers at Musselburgh Golf Club, which is well over a mile away at Monktonhall. The River Esk snakes around the edge of the course.Prof Crofts expressed concern that dogs could easily swallow them, resulting in ldquolarge vet bills for owners.After ing the balls to the club, he has issued a call for the flood protection scheme, currently being drawn up for Musselburgh, to include measures to slow down water coming off the Pentland and Moorfoot Hills where the North and South Esk rise.Prof Crofts, of Musselburghrsquos Eskside West, a geography expert who has worked as a research scientist in Scotland, said: ldquoAlong the golf course there are very soft banks and you can see where they have been cut back, and probably there was some rough at the end of the fairway where lots of people have lost balls.ldquoWe cannot stop leaves and tree trunks being brought down the river but the speed of rise of the water level and its velocity shows that any flood prevention scheme for Musselburgh needs to look hard at measures to slow down water coming off the hills and into the river. Without this, the erection of walls being proposed in Musselburgh will not be public money well spent.ldquoMany of us feel the importance of the amenity of this stretch of the river ndash it is very fine.He said a tree planting scheme using native species should be discussed with landowners in the headwaters of the Esk catchment area, as government grants were available for such work.He said: ldquoI am talking about hundreds of thousands of trees maybe. Careful hand planting of trees is best rather than using tractors to dig ditches to prepare the land for planting as this would aggravate the problem by increasing the rate of water running off the hills. The trees would take up water from the soil.ldquoThe use of the reservoirs on the North and South Esk and the temporary flooding of the flat land along the river should be seriously investigated to store water during heavy rainfall and therefore slow the release of water into the river.ldquoIf you look at the flood issue, itrsquos caused by the river rising very fast but itrsquos made worsethere are high spring tides and a storm surge in the North Sea, and also a northerly wind across the estuary which piles the water up high and stops the river water escaping for a couple of hours either side of high tide.Professor Crofts has raised his concerns with consultants who are drawing up the Musselburgh Flood Protection Scheme and he has also made local councillors aware of his views.As for the coast, he highlighted small sand dunes which formed a natural barrier with grasses, which, below the ground level, had yards of roots acting as a natural catcher of the sand.Jackie Lambert, captain of Musselburgh Golf Club, said: ldquoThe club was unaware of the issue regarding golf balls being found on the beach near the mouth of the River Esk.ldquoWhilst, the figure of  golf balls is signicant, it is unknown over what timescale these balls have accumulated andthey are all, indeed, from the course.ldquoNotwithstanding this, the golf club will happily participate in any working group looking at the wider issues of flood protection and the environment in and around Musselburgh. However, at this time we have not been invited to join any group.

title: 80-year-old-port-seton-pensioner-admits-breaching-asbo
story: Thomas Hamilton, , broke the rules of the ASBO imposed in April which had barred him from using aggressive, abusive or intimidating language or causing distress to neighbours at his Long Craigs home.He breached the order on August  when he was found to have used abusive language during an incident where he obstructed a parking bay during an argument with a neighbour.Hamilton also damaged a vehicle during the row near to his home.The OAP also assaulted neighbour Ian Hirst by struggling with him during a separate incident at Long Craigs on August .The pensioner was back in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday, where he pleaded guilty to the two offences.Sherf John Cook was told that Hamilton had a review of a previous case with another sherf in March next year and he was content to defer all matters to that date.No narration of the August events were read out in court and all matters were deferred to March .Hamilton admitted breaching his ASBO on August . He also admitted assaulting Mr Hirst by struggling with him at Long Craigs on August .

title: tims-tales-tunnel
story: It was one of a number of stories written by their class, who were encouraged to explore their creative writing by their then teacher Mr Andrew. I have edited it for publication here, but I have attempted to keep the story as close to the original as possible, and the story itself is completely the idea of the children.IN PRESTONPANS, there lived two nine-year-old children called Max and Lily.One day, they went on a bike ride to Preston Tower for a picnic. When they got there they laid a chequered blanket down on the grass, opened their basket and began to eat.They were about to leave after eating their food when they saw a robin perched on a nearby branch. It seemed friendly and the children fed the wee bird some of their leftovers.The robin then flew to a nearby abandoned cottage. The children were intrigued and followed the robin to investigate the cottage.They couldnrsquot remember noticing it before and they were wandering around it peering inside through small a gap in the wall. They couldnrsquot see where the robin had gone. They should have just left it but curiosity got the better of them and they searched for a way in. They were anxious to find out what had happened to the robin.But there was no way in, as the entrance and windows were blocked. So they clambered up the cottage wall, the bricks crumbling under their feet.Tired and exhausted, they finally reached where they thought the robin had landed.They found an opening which led to a dark passage. Despite being a bit scared, Max and Lily decided to investigate and walked down the passage. It was dimly lit by small gaps in the wall that let in narrow beams of light. At the end, there was a staircase. They huddled together as they walked.Then all of a sudden, the floorboard behind them collapsed.Now in fear and panic, they dashed up the steps of the dilapidated staircase into the attic.From the corner of the attic, they could just make out a small black figure running towards them.They thought they had seen the robin but it was something much worse. ldquoMouse! screamed Lily. Then they heard a glass shatter ndash smash!They were now terried and they sat in pitch darkness. The only light they had was the light that was seeping through the bricks in the walls.As they sat in fear, they realised they needed to come up with a plan to escape. They searched the cottage for a way out.As Lily investigated around the room, she tripped over a rug that seemed to have something poking upwards. She called out for Max and he came rushing down the stairs.As Max kneeled down to take a closer look, Lily revealed what looked like a trapdoor.Astonished, the children pulled the handle.It led to a tunnel which was flooded with candlelight. Who lit the candles  Max and Lily wonderedwhoever had lit the candles knew they were there.They entered the candlelit tunnel and one step at a time they cautiously moved forward.Then, slam! The trapdoor shut behind them and they jumped in fear. This was all too much for them to handle, they were desperate to get out.Then Max heard a soft but evil whisper: ldquoPlease stay, Irsquom lonely.In terror, he pulled out his phone and pressed  but it instantly shut off. ldquoPlease stay, said the voice, now sounding child-like.ldquoHelp! screamed Max and Lily through the gaps in the wall, but help never came.Then they heard something on the floorboards above.ldquoThere must be something up there, said Lily. ldquoI guess the only way out is to follow the candlelight.So they ventured further down the candlelit passageway.As the pair made their way through the tunnel, they could just make out what looked like a white figure approaching, who had a terrying grin with sharp teeth.Max and Lilyrsquos hearts beat uncontrollably as they sprinted away from this terrying image and as they did so all the candles blew out, throwing the children into complete darkness.Was this thing still there  The friends sat together in the darkness breathing heavily, in shock and terror.Suddenly, in the darkness, icy fingers gripped Lilyrsquos arms.ldquoWas that you rsquorsquo asked Lily. ldquoNo, replied Max.All at once, the candles lit up again. Max and Lily turned round and saw a horrying face: ldquoArghhhhhhh!They woke in the sunlight. ldquoWhat  said Max, confused. ldquoWhat just happened   added Lily.ldquoIt must have been a bad dream, said Max. ldquoBut both of us had the same dream, how is that possible ldquoWe had better go, they said.As they were about to leave, they saw a robin. They turned and looked at each other with a smirk on their faces and a chill in their bones.

title: port-seton-library-closing-refurbishment
story: The library, situated within the Port Seton Community Centre, closes on Monday and will re-open on Monday, December .During this period, customers will not be able to borrow books or other loans however, they canany loans to staff at the community centre and the outstanding loans period will be extended during the refurbishment work.Anyone wishing to use a computer will be able to do so within the community centre.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, council spokesperson for community wellbeing, said: ldquoOur investment in the refurbishment of the library will result in it being repainted and the carpeting being replaced, which means that it has to be completely emptied for the work to be carried out."Loans can still be taken out or ed at any of the other branches across East Lothian and we have made sure that two PCs will be available to use within the community centre.

title: pumpkin-patch-nursery-boss-admits-defeat-closing-dunbar-nursery
story: Jonathan Bruneau said the Dunbar branch of his Pumpkin Patch Nurseries would close permanently in two weeks after  years of looking after children in the town.The nursery was criticised in a recent Care Inspectorate report over changing staff and a lack of management.However, Mr Bruneau, who also has Pumpkin Patch nurseries in North Berwick and Haddington, said the problems had been created by Scottish Government demands.He said: ldquoUnfortunately we have had to admit defeat related to our ability to staff and manage our Dunbar setting.ldquoRecruiting management and senior staff has been impossible over recent years due to Scottish Government policies which have driven the average age and experience of nursery practitioners down to levels which are simply not appropriate to run a nursery.ldquoNursery staff work long hours for salaries which are not commensurate with the level of education and expertise they are expected to achieve.ldquoThis, plus the rolling out of , hours per year of free nursery care , has created a staffing crisis most noticeably felt in rural areas where staff cannot afford to travel from Edinburgh or beyond.ldquoThe final straw came when we lost our most recent manager after three months when she was poached by a nursery closer to home. This was inevitable as she had been travelling one hour each way to get to Dunbar and, even though subsidised by us to make the journey, a two-hour commute is simply not sustainable.Mr Bruneau warned of the impact of demands on private nurseries in April this year when his nursery in Haddington saw its grades fall in an inspection. He said: ldquoThis is a systematic problem which is causing a death spiral in the quality of nursery provision throughout the industry.The inspection report on Dunbarrsquos Pumpkin Patch rated its quality of care and support, staffing and management and leadership at twowith the environment rated a three .The report said that parents had contacted the inspectorate following its unannounced visit in August to discuss concerns.A high turnover in staff was raised by a number of parents, with one telling inspectors: ldquoOften when I drop my child off I have to introduce myself and my child to the agency staff.The report said: ldquoParents told us that they often did not know the staff when they dropped off their children in the morning, often resulting in their children being reluctant to attend.Mr Bruneau said that the introduction of mandatory SSSCregistration was creating recruitment problems throughout the industry.He said: ldquoBefore the advent of SSSC registration, our group of nurseries never used any agency staff as recruitment was simple. It included people of ying ages, experience and circumstance.ldquoIt was a healthy labour market now new staff are iniably under , inexperienced in le, work and certainly the care of children.ldquoNursery closures are inevitable as sites struggle to find staff, maintain standards and satisfy increased demand.He said his company had decided to rationalise itsservices, placing more experience in fewer sites, and called on the Scottish Government to reverse policies he said ruled out more mature staff from working in nurseries.He added that all five members of staff at Dunbar had been offered places at his other nurseries.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council, which used the Dunbar nursery as a partner provider, said: ldquoWe have worked with Pumpkin Patch as one of our partner providers, offering funded early learning and childcare for pre-school children for many years.ldquoOur officers have also provided extensive support to the Dunbar team to help them improve the quality of experiences following recent Care Inspectorate reports. Our assistance has been recognised and appreciated by the owners, who feel that we have done all we can to support them.ldquoWe acknowledge that this will have been a dficult decision for the owners and will have implications for their team at Dunbar. We also acknowledge the upset and disruption that the nursery closure will bring for parents using this service.ldquoOur staff will work with and support parents to find alternative early learning and childcare within the area that meets their needs.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoMore than , children are already benefiting from the expanded entitlement after we increased training opportunities and routes into the early learning and childcare sector, resulting in a record ,-strong workforce.ldquoWe are working alongside local authorities and providers to ensure the necessary workforce is in place ndash including running a national early learning and childcare recruitment campaign, increasing support for training places and modern apprenticeships, and enabling providers to advertise jobs free on the MyJobScotland website.

title: pensioner-completes-74-year-quest-discover-father
story: David Simpson had spent  years looking for his dad after growing up in a Quarriers orphanage to the west of Glasgow before moving across the Atlantic.But his attempts proved fruitless until a visit to long-lost family in Elgin last year.John Hamilton, from Lost Haddington, then became aware of Mr Simpsonrsquos quest.He said: ldquoFrom the information David received from Quarriers, all he knew was that his father was a Jack Cunningham, a plasterer from Goodallrsquos Place in Haddington.ldquoHis niece AnnMarie Whyte did a search for Goodallrsquos Place and the result came back with a find against a Lost Haddington image for the old Goodallrsquos shop on the townrsquos Bridge Street this led to AnnMarie posting a question askingI knew who Jack Cunningham was.ldquoA search of the Lost Haddington collection for Cunningham brought back too many matches, so the search was honed to lsquoplastererrsquo and the results produced the equivalent of a Holy Grail image ndash a George Angus scan of a lsquoJohnrsquo Cunninghamrsquos security application to RAF East Fortune.As well as correcting the name, the image confirmed his occupation and address, as well as his height, hair and eye colour.A plea was put on social media for further information, which found that Johnrsquos nickname was lsquoGibbyrsquo and that David had a cousin living in Musselburgh called Janette Brotherstone.Mr Hamilton said: ldquoAlso, a further search of Lost Haddington for the word lsquoGibbyrsquo, with it being an unusual name, produced another George Angus image from  showing Davidrsquos father John when he was only five or six years old holding the date plate for his school photo ndash George had annotated the image saying the lsquoboy holding the date slate was Gibby Cunninghamrsquo, so when I sent David this image it was the first time hersquod seen his father.ldquoThe feedback from the Lost Haddington followers also indicated that John died in  when he lived at No  St Annrsquos Place.ldquoThrough the invaluable feedback which named Janette as his first cousin, David was put in touch with her and shersquos since sent him some old family photos showing his father throughout his le.ldquoThe photos came from Davidrsquos fatherrsquos home, where he died, as it was Janette who dealt with the death notices for both Davidrsquos father and Johnrsquos we Jessie Cagder.ldquoDavid visited Scotland in autumn  so I offered to bring him to Haddington, which he accepted.From there, David, who now lives in Rochester, New York, was able to see the home where his dad was born on Haddingtonrsquos St Martinrsquos Gate, as well as his homes on Goodallrsquos Place and St Annrsquos Place.It is thought Davidrsquos dad was lodged with a landlady while working in Elgin in .According to Mr Hamilton: ldquoThe landladyrsquos husband was away from home for two years as a soldier in World War Two and itrsquos during this period that John and the landlady must have had a moment of indiscretion together, which produced David!ldquoWhen the landladyrsquos husband ed home from the war due to injury and found his we holding baby David ndash that couldnrsquot have been his ndash he gave his we the ultimatum: lsquoTake him to the orphanage or itrsquos a orce.rsquoldquoAt the age of around one month old, David was taken to the Quarriers orphanage which is near the Bridge of Weir to the west of Glasgow.David left Quarriers at the age of  and eventually moved to Winnipeg in Canada in  before eventually settling in New York.More than  years ago, he began his bid to track down his family. title: josh-taylors-girlfriend-says-boxing-star-dedicating-world-title-win-late-dad-means-world-me

title: school-pupils-tranent-come-together-climate-conversation
story: A Big Climate Conversation was held in St Martinrsquos Church Hall last Friday.School pupils were the main organisers of the event, marketed as: ldquoWhat the hell do the kids in Tranent know about climate change The community was welcomed to share their views on how Scotland can respond to the global climate emergency and feedback will be provided to the Scottish Government.The interactive conversation was led by children and featured games and music encouraging the people of Tranent to think about climate change as a human rights issue which must be addressed.The children in charge made sure the event was as carbon neutral as possible and even rented reusable plastic plates from Lower Impact Living, East Saltoun, to serve food on.At the end of the event, they had participants make pledges about what they were personally going to do to help tackle climate change.The event was organised by volunteers from Ross High School, Pencaitland Primary School, St Martinrsquos Eco Group, Farsquoside Womenrsquos Group and the Childrenrsquos Parliament and was sponsored by the Scottish Governmentrsquos The Big Climate Conversation Community Fund.Amy Gossner, , from Ross High School, was one of the youngsters key in organising the event and said: ldquoWe want everyone to be more aware of climate change.ldquoI think a lot of people donrsquot realise how much climate change is going to impact everyone in the future.ldquoItrsquos not just happening on TV, itrsquos happening everywhere in the world and itrsquos everyonersquos responsibility.ldquoOur aim is to find out what people in the community, especially children, think is the way forward and what they think other people can do to help prevent climate change.Claire MacGillivray, a Trustee of the Childrenrsquos Parliament, said: ldquoOn the back of this event, we will be sending a report to the Scottish Government but I think itrsquos really about starting the conversation.We have a reason to make the world a better place: for our children. They are taking the lead by showing adults that they want things to change.Paul Reynolds, headteacher at Ross High School, said: ldquoI am delighted that our pupils are proactively seeking to raise awareness of these issues and look at ways to make positive changes.ldquoWe also have a group looking at ways to highlight this important issue in school so this is clearly an issue which means a lot to our pupils.The Big Climate Conversation Community Fund was launched in August to assist community organisations to host workshops and engage in the climate change debate. It is managed by Impact Funding on behalf of the Scottish Government.Sixty-two groups have been approved to receive funding so far which project to engage more than , members of the public in the climate conversation.

title: liberal-democrats-formally-adopt-general-election-candidate-east-lothian
story: The Lib Dems had been the first party to select a General Election candidate in the county, announcing back in March that the partys East Lothian convenor Robert ORiordan would be their prospective candidate in the anticipation of an election being held in the near future.Now that a General Election has been formally announced for December , the Lib Dems formally adopted Mr ORiordan as their candidate for East Lothian at a meeting in Haddington.Mr OrsquoRiordan has lived in Gullane since . title: east-lothian-council-solar-panels-win
story: Councillors gave the go-ahead for  solar  to be placed on the roof of a new hostel which is to be developed in Dunbar town centre, despite planning officers ruling it breached the councilrsquos conservation area rules.The hostel, which is being developed at the former Dolphin Inn and Hotel, on the townrsquos Queens Road, is the brainchild of environmentalist Jo Waddell, who wants to create a boutique hostel for young people and active tourists.However, planning officers recommended that while The Dolphin InnLtdrsquos hostel plan was given the go-ahead, the solar  on its roof should be rejected.They warned councillorsthe ldquoshiny, reflective finish of the  would be harmful to the character and appearance of the building.And they said allowing the  would set a precedent for the townrsquos conservation area.Ms Waddell toldcouncillors at a planning committee meeting inthat she was trying to protect the old building, urging them to think of Dunbarrsquos most famous son, naturalist John Muir, and what he would have thought of how things were today.She asked: ldquoWhat would he say to us putting shiny over common sense Alasdair Swan, speaking on behalf of Dunbar Community Council, said lsquoSunny Dunnyrsquo, as the town is affectionately known because of its high number of sunshine hours, would welcome the solar .He said: ldquoWersquod like to record our extreme gratitude to Jo for her investment in the Dolphin.ldquoWe have this balance between a policy to preserve a conservation area just as it is and a policy where the council has to do something about climate change.ldquoThis is an issue that needs to be resolved sooner rather than later.ldquoWe are comfortable with the realisation that this could set a precedent.Councillor NormanHampshire, planning convenor and local ward member, who led the successful motion by the council to declare a climate emergency at a meeting in August, said members had to choose between investment in sustainableenergy and conservation.He told fellow councillors: ldquoWe have agreed there is a climate emergency and we need to take action to do what we can to reduce our carbon footprint in East Lothian.ldquoIf we refuse this it means the climate emergency declarations will be a complete joke.Councillor Sue Kempson, fellow ward member for Dunbar and East Linton, also supported the solar .She said: ldquoThe new owners have the energy and enthusiasm to commit to a much-needed facility for Dunbar.Councillors unanimously agreed to amend the planning officersrsquo recommendation and allow the solar  as part of the approval for the hostel.Councillor Neil Gilbert told the committee: ldquoHopefully we can look back on this day as a watershed.

title: bake-offs-flora-shedden-my-generation-delusional-approach-food
story: If the Think Global, Eat Local mantra is being appropriated by mindful Millennials , then Flora Shedden is arguably a standard-bearer of the generations she spans. Originally coined some years ago by older campaigners wishing for a more sustainable, secure and resilient system of food production and distribution, the -year-old Scot is taking up the baton ndash albeit it on a tiny Perthshire footprint.Four years ago, at the age of , the Dunkeld-born student became the youngest-ever finalist in the long-running reality baking show The Great British Bake-Off [GBBO]. Watched by  million viewers worldwide, she was the runner-up in the  finale and instantly became a media darling. Evidently thrilled and reassured in equal measure to have such a young woman embrace ndash in her reassuring mid-Scots accent ndash the ancient culinary art of baking using centuries-old techniques, print and broadcast commissioning editors flocked to her oven door. Her first cookbook was published, and her online presence rose faster than the lightest souffle. Here was a new domestic goddess in whose delicate hands baking was safe. The world, it seemed, was her ice-cream oyster.Then she turned the tables. Eschewing the bright lights, she has settled instead for her own tiny craft bakery in a th century village in rural Perthshire where she quietly and happily puts in a -hour day. Itrsquos from this modest ndashinfinitely pretty ndash base that she hopes to influence our relationship with food for the better.Not that shersquos about to disappear completely: with its white-painted -year-old stone walls, original black range, front door draped with garlands of dried flowers, the setting for her glass-fronted display of fresh craft bakery items, Aran, is the last word in Instagrammability. Named after the Gaelic for bread, it is also the title of her second cookbook.ldquoYeah, it was a bit of a ballsy move, she agrees of her snap decision to buy the bakery in . ldquoItrsquos been wonderful. I call it my flour oasis. Wersquore perched on little white-painted stepping stools in a corner of the busy shop floor, trying not to get in the way of the constant stream of customers ndash a combination of locals and tourists ndash looking for her trademark homemade croissants, cakes, pastries and sourdough breads which have sustainability hard-baked into every bite.Shedden put her studies on hold ndash she was doing a history of art degree at St Andrews ndash to set up Aran with her friend Angus and her boyfriend of just five months at the time, James Irvine, who now manages the Birnam Arts Centre. The pair live together in the flat above the shop. A crowdfunding campaign raised pound, for refurbishment and grants from the SSE windfarm community fund, combined with a bank loan and proceeds from her first book Gatherings, made her long-held dream possible.ldquoIrsquod immediately become jealous when Angus told me he had a lsquobread shedrsquo, a place where he would create loaves upon loaves post-work and early in the morning, she says. ldquoHis magic little set-up was exactly what I had been looking for. It took a year for the trio and other family and friends to get the bakery open.I remark on how busy Aran is, and am informed it does some  transactions a day . The elongated Scottish tourist season means they are busy all year round rather than the traditional Easter to September.ldquoPeople have no idea how much work goes into this and how much we bake every single day, she says. A production kitchen on a small industrial park up the road in Birnam has helped alleviate the flow.So far, so impressive.But Irsquom intrigued.Alongside gorgeous recipes on how to make the goodies in the bakery ndash think Whisky Eccles cakes, pistachio and lime loaf, or butternut squash and Birnam honey loafndash her new book features little drop-in biogs of her regular customers and staff, many of them men, and also of her father. So the female vibe of her previous book, in which she praised the influence of women on home cooking, seems to have morphed into something more collegiate and collaborative ndash as well as less sugary-sweet. Aran follows a day in the le of the bakery, hour by hour and ritual by ritual, and there are recipes for sandwiches, salads, savoury tarts and sandwiches ndash and a heavy emphasis on sourdough breads, brioches and croissants.So, does running a bakery span the genders  ldquoYeah, it used to be all women but the balance is more even now. In fact, I call my team lsquoThe Boysrsquo, she says. ldquoGatherings was more focused on home and family whereas this is much bigger and wider in scope and people. What wersquore doing here is definitely more collaborative. People of both genders bring in ideas and suggestions, either orally or from memory, and we try them out. Wersquore doing continual RD and things are developing organically. And in the village, the wider community spirit is strong.She makes a point of sourcing ingredients, including the all-important flour, from the community and from Scotland as much as possible. Salmon is from the Dunkeld Smoke House, honey from master beekeeper John Taylor, and fresh produce is from the organic Dunkeld and Birnam Community Growing, known as The Field, and from Blackhall Farm. Butter is from Grahamrsquos Dairies, although her Lescure patisserie butter ndash good for croissants and pastries due to its high fat content ndash is from France. With Brexit in mind, she is looking for alternative local sources to provide her with the  kilos she goes through every week.ldquoThe really important thing for us is to be sustainable, she says.Her message about eating sensibly is also strong, and she cites the Rome-based food writer Rachel Roddy and the Irish writer Diana Henry as her food heroes for their ldquosensible approach to healthy eating.In Aran, she writes: ldquoSugar gets a bad rep, as does gluten, sadly. But my principles remain the same throughout this bizarre time. Use proper and honest ingredients and think of food as a source of fuel and satisfaction, not as something to fear or discuss negatively.Kale, which she says, ldquogets all the attention by the clean-eaters, and I worry it will put people off it, features strongly in her salad section alongside squash, carrot tops, heirloom tomatoes and asparagus. Therersquos a foraged nettle and pea quiche in a nod to Scottish culinary history and nettle pudding, ldquothe oldest recorded pudding in the book, but unlikely to make a reappearance.Her misgivings echo those expressed in the  Gatherings, in which she lamented the number of people of her age-group that she knew to have eating disorders or troubled relationships with food, and how ldquoearth-shattering that could be.The equal balance between sweet and savoury in Aran is notable, and again echoes the authorrsquos desire to change perceptions that baking is all about sweetness and stodge.Does she think her peer-group ndash at almost  she is somewhere between a Millennial and the younger so-called Generation Z ndash are confused about food and diet  ldquoYes, she replies, without hesitation. ldquoI am from the generation with arguably the most delusional approach to food. Therersquos so much noise surrounding it on social media. The influencer set are hugely to blame when it comes to diet issues. People arenrsquot sure about where they stand as they receive mixed messages almost every day.With veganism gaining in popularity among Gen Zedders, does she offer vegan options  ldquoA couple, but thatrsquos not something we do massively, she replies, with an almost imperceptible sigh. ldquoApart from the fact that itrsquos very hard to cater for every possible dietary requirement, our ethos here is hugely based on local, as opposed to dietary.ldquoTherersquos quite a contentious discourse about veganism. I think itrsquos doing more damage to the planet than eating dairy from the farm  miles down the road."As well as her concerns about food miles, she also has health worries. ldquoI think itrsquos crazy to eliminate so many food groups at once, as veganism advocates. Itrsquos about cutting out a huge amount of the foods wersquove been eating for thousands of years. Problems seem to have occurred with the processed foods wersquove had available for the last  years. Tradition has never done us any harm. Now everyonersquos terried about their health.Sipping milky tea and casting an eye over the ever-forming queue at the counter, she continues: ldquoIt makes me laugh when people come in to our bakery looking for gluten-free. But you can eat our sourdough bread because itrsquos slow-fermented for  hours, which reduces the gluten content dramatically, is more easily digested and therefore better for your gut. I spend a lot of time trying to tell people to try sourdough because itrsquos the best thing you can possibly eat.ldquoI tell them thatthey buy a supermarket loaf they should toast it before eating it to finish off the baking. Itrsquos over-processed and over-yeasted to bake in minutes rather than days and contains  ingredients instead of just three or four. When you eat it itrsquos going to keep cooking in your stomach and make you feel heavy and bloated. Bread should never feel heavy.ldquoEverything processed is why wersquove lost touch with fresh food. E-numbers, additives, colourants, preservatives and so on are all man-made and, of course, theyrsquore going to cause damage and health problems. Naturally occurring ingredients are hardly to blame.Traditional Scottish iced gingerbread, almond and pistachio croissants and chocolate brownies are her biggest sellers. ldquoItrsquos OK to have sugar in moderation. Little and often, she says, smiling. Her own favourites are the sourdough sandwiches made fresh every day and filled with locally sourced greenery. ldquoWe donrsquot do them to order, otherwise wersquod be making cheese and ham every day, she says, grinning.She already has her eyes on the future, and hopes to open a village greengrocers soon. ldquoWe want to stay in Dunkeld and open a village store where things will be properly sourced and we can support the local area, she says. ldquoAt the moment we can only buy plastic-wrapped apples from Spain at the local Co-op. Wersquod like to further help the local growers and producers, while completing the circular system in terms of sustainability, cutting food waste and increasing food security.She concedes that shersquos in the privileged position of being in the main street of a historic village which is popular with tourists with no large supermarkets or fast-food chains to dilute her influence. The local independent butcher, smokehouse, deli and whisky shop are hardly going to do that. In fact, she believes she is part of wider grassroots movement in Scotland that is being fed ndash and in turn consumed ndash by social media.The downside of being part of the Gen Z zeitgeist is she has in the past fallen foul of social mediarsquos more unpleasant side. A self-taught cook who grew up in Dunkeld, Shedden suffered a Twitter backlash when, as a contestant on GBBO, she said shersquod forgotten to switch on the electric oven because her parents had an Aga at home that she had over  cookbooks, most of them French and that she had picked up a recipe for biscotti while travelling in Italy. Such comments resulted in the Twittersphere posting that she was ldquotoo posh, ldquotoo middle-class and ldquotoo professional ndash comments that were picked up by the tabloids.She says now: ldquoI havenrsquot been on Twitter for months. I love Instagram, itrsquos a great way to communicate and a huge part of our business comes through it. It also helped us market our Crowdfunding campaign. It is about sharing. It is far more my vibe and less threatening than Twitter.ldquoThrough Instagram it never fails to amaze me how many fantastic wee independent food places, producers and initiatives there are right across Scotland now, she adds. ldquoI think people are a lot more aware of what theyrsquore eating and where their food comes from. They are aware of sourcing and what theyrsquore putting in their systems. Theyrsquore more interested in that than in price. I like to think that from our tiny part of the planet wersquore changing things bit by bit.Aran, Recipes and Stories from a Bakery in the Heart of Scotland, by Flora Shedden, is published by Hardie Grant at pound.BUTTERNUT SQUASH AND BIRNAM HONEYWe do our absolute best to source as many local ingredients as possible, and always encourage customers to come through the door with any of their own goods. One day, we received a wonky squash from a local gardener and a couple of jars of Birnam honey from a lovely man called Mark, and we knew we had to combine them. This is a mash-up of the only three recipes I could find that contained more butternut squash than sugarand the end result is quite unique. Not dissimilar to a tea cake, the crumb is very soft, and perfect with a cup of Lady Grey tea.Makes xgloafor a xxcmloaf gbutternut squash, peeledand roughly chopped sunflower oil, for roasting gunsalted butter gsoft brown sugar grunny honey egg gself-raising flour ggroundalmonds  golive oil ggolden raisinszest of  orangefrac teaspoon mixed spiceDemerara sugar, for scatteringPreheat the oven to C . Grease and line a loaf tin.Tip the squash into a roasting tin and drizzle with a little oil, but with no seasoning, which will feel bizarreyour roast a lot of veg. Cook for  minutes or until soft and tender ndash it doesnrsquot need to be too well coloured. We tend to roast a big batch, remove the amount needed for this recipe once cooked, then season the rest and use in salads. Let the squash cool down before blitzing to form a smooth pureacutee.In the bowl of a free-standing mixer, beat the butter, sugar and honey until smooth and pale. Add the egg, flour, almonds,using, and oil. Beat again until fully combined. Add the cooled pureacutee, raisins, zest and spice and mix together by hand. Pour into the prepared tin, sprinkle generously with Demerara sugar and bake for ndash minutes, or until cooked through and a kne inserted into the middle comes out clean.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Everyone   s on a loser in the Brexit General Election race
story: OK: Europe was always going to dominate, but why do all the parties seem to lose any sense of reality as soon as they talk about it :Brexit lsquocould mean border checks between England, Scotland and WalesrsquoJeremy Corbyn made a valiant effort yesterday to pretend that Brexit was really about the NHS. Malign forces are gathering in Mordor, in the shape of American pharmaceutical companies, waiting for their Dark Lord Trump to gobble up the NHS and force costly medicines down our throats.The Labour leader then came out with a claim that Brexit would cost the NHS pound million extra per week in higher medicine costs. This was remarkable for being even dafter than the poundm on the side of Boris Johnsonsrsquos Big Red Bus.:If Labour win, itll be less like Venezuela than Britain circa It is based on a remark ndash subsequently retracted by Donald Trump ndash that ldquoeverything would be on the table in trade talks with the UK. The POTUS was talking even more nonsense than usual because there really is no prospect of a public service like the NHS being anywhere near the table in trade talks. And thatrsquos not me talking, but the Nuffield Trust, the leading NHS think tank.Nor is there a serious risk of American pharmaceutical companies forcing up the cost of medicines through open competition, as Mr Corbyn claims. The reason, according to the Nuffield, is because competitive tendering for drug prices has been going on for decades, and the NHS does very well out of it. As the biggest health-care purchaser on the planet, it gets the best prices from Big Pharma.The purpose of all this was to ert attention from Labourrsquos actual policy on Brexit, which is not to have any policy at all. ldquoWe recognise why people voted Leave we recognise why people voted Remain, said Labourrsquos Employment spokeswoman, Laura Pidcock, yesterday. ldquoWe are not the party of either: we are the party of both.Therersquos a philosophical debate to be had on whether it is possible to be both for and against Brexit. But in politics itrsquos usually called ldquonot having a clue. Labour intends to negotiate a new Brexit deal in three months, and then put that to a referendum in another three months. Thus will Britain be inof the EU by next June."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media mHMQRD poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests mHMQRD.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Letrsquos set aside, for the moment, the fact that Brussels says it is not prepared to reopen the Withdrawal Deal, for a third time, or extend Article , for a fourth time. Labourrsquos Shadow Brexit Secretary, Keir Starmer, says the European Union will accept Labour terms because theyrsquoll be all about ldquostaying in the customs union and in regulatory alignment with the single market.:Decision to omit SNP from Sky election debate defies democracy says Nicola SturgeonIn other words, this means rejoining the EU in all but name, as the head of Labour for a Peoplersquos Vote, Mike Buckley, admitted on LBC yesterday. But it would mean restoring free movement, joining the European Economic Area , continuing to pay into the EU budget , accepting EU trade negotiations and remaining under the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice.But these are things that Labour have repeatedly said they do not want. Mr Johnson surprised MPs by delivering a new Brexit deal, with the Irish backstop moved to the Irish Sea. But the UK would still remain under Brussels rule during the transition period and could still find itself beholden the ECJ in the subsequent trade deal.He has gone the long way round Brexit and found himself back where he started. Nigel Farage and his Brexit Party are not going to let him forget that  per cent of the new Brexit deal is actually the old Theresa May Brexit Deal.Tory hard-liners agree, but they are keeping quiet because they realise that,they donrsquot back Mr Johnsonrsquos Brexit, they probably wonrsquot get any Brexit at all. Their hopes are pinned now on forcing a World Trade Organisation trade deal after the transition period and delivering hard Brexit by stealth.As for the voters, I suspect many of them just want to see the whole Brexit madness stopped. Which to be fair is what the Liberal Democrats are proposing: to revoke Article . But there is one slight problem with this: the UK voted to leave the EU.It might very well do so again in a repeat referendum. But the Liberal Democrat ldquoPM-in-waiting, Jo Swinson, says shersquod just ignore that. Itrsquos like the head girl telling everyone that they canrsquot have fizzy drinks. After all, it is calling for a new referendum on Scottish independence to keep us in the EU.But has the SNP thought this through  By agreeing a confirmatory vote on the new Brexit deal, does that not also mean agreeing, in principle, to a confirmatory vote on any deal after indyref Nicola Sturgeon insists that the two are ldquoof course completely dferent. But unless she wants to crash out of the UK, therersquoll have to be a deal with London. No one can know the nature of that deal ndash on currency, debt, borders, customs and regulatory alignment ndash until after it has been negotiated.So, the SNP position begins to looklike not one, but three referendums. title: glasgow-named-culture-capital-uk
story: Scotlands most populated city took the top spot in the Cultural and Creative Cities Monitor  report.The study from the EUs executive arm ranks  cities in  European countries on their "cultural vibrancy", "creative economy", and ability to attract creative talent and stimulate cultural engagement.London, Bristol, Brighton and Manchester round out the rest of the top five, with Edinburgh in sixth place.: and : Glasgow embraces a year of cultureDundee was the next ranked Scottish city, coming in th place.Glasgow is top for "openness, tolerance and trust", and "cultural participation and attractiveness", according to the report.Edinburgh is named the best UK city for cultural venues and facilities.The report states: "Glasgow was one of the first European capitals of culture, in . Known as an industrial city, it has now gained recognition as a creative and cultural centre of European importance."Bridget McConnell, chair of Glasgow Le which delivers cultural and sports events for Glasgow City Council, said: "We always knew Glasgow was a global cultural leader and were delighted that the European Commission has confirmed our position of the UKs leading cultural and creative city."Glasgow is a city bursting with energy, passion and creativity and filled with artists, designers, creators and innovators. We have world-class museums and galleries, incredible architecture and history and, as a Unesco City of Music, theres nowhere better to enjoy a gig."Whats more, our openness, tolerance and trust has been rated as the best in Europe, confirming what we already know, that our people make Glasgow the best city in the world.":Glasgow confirmed as host venue for COP climate summitGlasgow is home to more than  cultural organisations and five of Scotlands six internationally renowned national performing arts companies.The council claims more people visit Glasgows museums each year than in any other UK city outside of London.Eight Turner Prize winners have hailed from, trained in, or worked out of the city in recent years.
